talk.start.para: - Is the Minister for Repatriation able to confirm reports that ex-servicemen who are inmates of repatriation hospitals but are not in receipt of pensions will no longer be required to leave such hospitals at the expiration of 90 days as patients, but may remain in hospital for the duration of their illness?
- I did not hear the whole of the honorable senator's question. I understood him to ask whether patients in repatriation hospitals who had been there for three months would get sustenance -
- And be allowed to remain in the hospital during the period of their illness; in other words, that they will not be thrown out.

- They have never been thrown out. The fact is that in respect of certain ailments - those of 100 per cent, disability such as totally and permanently incapacitated pensioners - there are facilities in the repatriation hospitals for -other than their war-caused disabilities. However, the period as a rule is not longer than three months. According to the Repatriation Act a patient suffering from a chronic complaint is not entitled to stay in the hospital for more than three months, but if it is thought that he will recover I am sure that the hospital authorities will allow him to remain until he is better, or has recovered sufficiently to go into another hospital. I repeat that patients have never been thrown out of repatriation hospitals.

- In view of the national importance of the floating dock at Newcastle, is the Minister for Shipping and Transport in a position to advise the Senate when the last survey of the dock was made, and will he assure the Senate that proper maintenance and repairs to this vital establishment are carried out?

- I can only tell the honorable senator that I have no information about the matter that he has raised.

- In view of the press reports about the serious nature of the Suez Canal situation, will the Attorney-General inform the Senate whether Mr. Casey has reported to the Cabinet about this matter, and when the Senate is likely to be informed officially about the situation?

- I am pleased, as I am sure all honorable senators are pleased, that Senator Aylett appreciates the seriousness and delicacy of the situation overseas. I can assure him, and the Senate, that as soon as the time is appropriate a full statement about the situation will be made.

- The relevant figures with regard to the level of the special accounts with the Commonwealth Bank are published at regular intervals. I have not the figures in my memory at present. As to the method in which these funds are employed. I prefer, having regard to the technicalities of the matter, that the honorable senator should put his question on notice so that the Treasurer himself may supply an answer to it.

- I refer to the statement made last week by the Minister for Shipping, and the fact that he has exempted the refrigeration ship " Viti " from the clauses of the Navigation Act to allow it to trade on the north and north-west coasts of Tasmania. I ask the Minister: What is the refrigerating capacity of this vessel, what is its tonnage and draught, and will it be able to service the ports of Ulverstone, Devonport, Launceston and Stanley to carry the greater proportion of refrigerated cargo from those ports?

talk.start.para: - On 4th September, 1956, Senator Anderson asked the following question: -

quote.para: I direct' a question to the Minister representing the Minister for Health, and preface it by pointing out that in the United States of America a new anti-polio vaccine is being manufactured under the name of Sabin, which certain medical authorities consider may prove to have more lasting immunizing qualities than the present vaccine Salk. Will the Minister have this report investigated, and if necessary, send an appropriate medical officer overseas to investigate Sabin vaccine?

question.para: The Minister for Health has now furnished the following reply: -

quote.para: There are fundamental differences between the Salk and Sabin vaccines which must be clearly understood in any consideration of their respective values. The Salk-type poliomyelitis vaccine as made by the Commonwealth Serum Laboratories and used in Australia is a mixed vaccine of virulent virus strains which have been killed. It is given by injection. The virulence of the virus evokes an effectual measure of protective response in the inoculated subject whilst the fact that it is not living assures that he will not communicate infection to contacts. The value of the Salk-type vaccine as a protection against poliomyelitis has been amply demonstrated by the successful immunization of millions of children throughout the world.

The Sabin vaccine, on the other hand, consists of living strains of virus selected for their lack of virulence. It may be given by mouth and for the best results it appears desirable that a vaccine for each poliomyelitis type be given on separate occasions. The virus multiplies in the body and actually infects the inoculated subject, who subsequently discharges the virus in his excreta for some weeks. The reaction of the body to this infection is claimed to build up a level of resistance to poliomyelitis in the same way and to the same level as follows an actual attack of poliomyelitis. It is argued that resistance will be more enduring than that likely to result from immunization with killed virus as in Salk-type vaccine, but evidence at present available does not support this view.

The confidence of the advocates of the Sabintype vaccine is not shared by all medical authorities. Doubts attach to the production of an effectual level of protection unless virulent organisms are used. It has not yet been convincingly proved that the attenuated living virus will not revert to virulence as it is disseminated through a community. As the subject immunized by the Sabin method excretes living organisms for some weeks after taking the vaccine, any such reversion to virulence would be attended by serious risk of infection to contacts. To date the Sabintype vaccine has been submitted to no extensive field trials and it is not in process of manufacture on a large scale. It is virtually still in the stage of laboratory study.

Honorable senators may be assured that my department will watch the development of the Sabin-type vaccine closely and consider its production and use in Australia if and when this seems desirable. It is proposed that Dr. Bazeley, Director of the Commonwealth Serum Laboratories, should visit the United States shortly and whilst there he will devote some time to a study of the Sabin-type vaccine and its potential. Meantime, in the Salk vaccine we have a proved effectual agent of protection against poliomyelitis which we will continue to use to the limit of our capacity.

quote.para: That all the words after "That" be left out with a view to insert in lieu thereof: - " the Estimates and Budget Papers 1956-57 tabled in the Senate are unacceptable and should be rejected because they seek to implement policies which are seriously detrimental in their effect on the interests of Australia and for which the Government deserves to be censured ".

talk.start.para: . - Continuing the remarks I began yesterday, I should like now to congratulate my leader, Senator McKenna, on the speech he delivered on behalf of the Opposition in connexion with the budget. Needless to say, I wholeheartedly support the amendment he has moved. I dealt at some length with some of the problems mentioned by honorable senators on the Government side, and the only other matter to which I wish to refer now is immigration. I believe that we must have immigration if this nation is to develop, but it must be planned immigration. During the 1920's we saw the spectacle of immigrants coming to this country when we had no work or homes to offer them. A similar position is arising to-day. This country is being inundated with immigrants from overseas and, when they arrive, the State governments have cast upon them the responsibility of housing and finding work for them. The States have no plans for employing these immigrants in a way calculated to serve both their interests and those of the nation. Immigrants are still coming to this country, despite the fact that there are thousands of unemployed immigrants already here. If we are to continue with a policy of immigration, the Government should at least have some reasonable plan for absorbing the immigrants as they arrive.

speech.para: During the course of debates in this Parliament, especially those on budgets, we hear honorable senators on the Government side continually blaming the succession of Labour governments for the position in which the country is placed to-day. I have often heard honorable senators opposite criticizing the late James Scullin and his

Government. Now we hear them criticizing what they are pleased to call socialist governments, those led by the late Mr. Curtin and the late Mr. Chifley. I should like to remind the Senate that, when the present Prime Minister (Mr. Menzies), and the present Treasurer (Sir Arthur Fadden), played politics and deserted this country in its hour of need, it was the great Australian Labour party that provided men with the necessary courage and ability to govern Australia and plan its war effort. Nobody can deny that a great job was done by the Labour Administration during the period of World War II. During the last 40 years, Labour has really governed for only six years. Even during the regime of the Scullin Government, Labour was faced with a hostile Senate, because there were only three Labour senators.

talk.start.para: - Why did not Labour seek a double dissolution?

- Labour did not ask for a double dissolution because the late Mr. Scullin was prepared to go to any lengths in order to set even the keel of the great ship of state. He believed that the legislation that he intended to introduce was in the best interests of the people. He was not prepared to resort to any political tricks in order to beguile the people of Australia into believing that a double dissolution would accomplish things that should be done. From 1941 to 1943, when Labour was in office, it had a minority in both Houses, but from 1943 to 1949 it had a majority in both Houses. Therefore, although Labour was in office for ten and a half years during the last 40 years, it was in effective control of the country for only six years. Despite that fact, many supporters of the Government continue to assert that the present parlous state of the nation is due to the activities of the previous socialist Labour administration.

speech.para: I should like now to refer to the reply by the Attorney-General and Minister for the Navy (Senator O'sullivan) to the observations that were - made by the Leader of the Opposition (Senator McKenna). The Minister said -

quote.para: As a result of recommendations by the Tariff Board, I am proud to say that this Government has increased customs duties for the purpose of protecting and encouraging worth-while and efficient Australian secondary industries. If the Leader of the Opposition is implying that the
Labour party is not in favour of protecting Australian industries, I invite honorable senators on the Opposition side who support that proposition to stand and say so.

speech.para: Did honorable senators ever hear anything so ridiculous? The Labour party brought the Tariff Board into existence, and has always wholeheartedly supported it, but the Tariff Board has very little to do with the import restrictions that are crippling industry to-day. The Leader of the Opposition (Senator McKenna) said that the present Government parties won the 1954 elections on the Petrov issue by adopting snide tactics. The political tactics of the Government in that instance have meant a loss to-day of £30.000,000 to the wool-growers of Australia.

talk.start.para: - How does the honorable senator make that out?

- If the honorable senator will take the trouble to examine statistics, he will find that my statement is correct. That is not because Russia has not received Australian wool. Russia has received our wool, but only after Russian agents have bought it at sales in England. At sales held in Australia that wool was bought by buyers acting on behalf of wool magnates in England, who later resold it in London to the Russians. They made a profit on that £30,000,000, notwithstanding that they had probably never seen an Australian sheep, or even Australia.

speech.para: The position facing us to-day is that Australia has lost many of its export markets. The Minister for Trade (Mr. McEwen) is telling us so every day. We should realize that by selling our wool to Russia we do not necessarily have to agree with Russian political philosophy any more than we accept Chinese political philosophy merely because we may sell some wheat or wool to China. The fact remains that whether we sell our products to those nations directly, or refuse to do so, they will certainly obtain our wool and other products if they need them and have the wherewithal to buy them. If they do not buy their requirements in Australia, they get them in other ways. I charge supporters of the Government, who frequently criticize members of the Labour party and accuse them of being tied to the Communist element in the world, with being themselves the people who are working hand-in-glove with those who control Soviet Russia to-day. There is a definite connexion between them and the Communists because they believe in communism, fascism and nazism. They do not believe in socialism or in the principles which the Labour party supports. The Petrov royal commission was only a political trick to win an election and to remove the Russian legation from Australia so that people overseas who had farmed the farmers for years could continue to do so. Those people who say that we have lost the Russian market should realize that Russia still gets our wool. No honorable senator can deny that that is so.

talk.start.para: - How much of our wool does Russia get?

- I do not know, but I do know that the party to which the honorable senator belongs pulled the political wool over the eyes of the people in connexion with the Petrov commission. It is interesting to note that in this year's Estimates a sum of £6,000 is provided for the Petrovs. I do not know why, nor do I care why it is provided, but that provision is being made. An age pensioner who was born in this country, reared a family here, and whose members have fought for it, is left with only £4 a week on which to live; yet this great traitor, who was prepared to sell even his wife, is paid £6,000 a year. Yet, we are told that crime does not pay!

speech.para: The Leader of the Government in this chamber (Senator O'sullivan) told us that the Menzies Administration had inspired confidence in Australia overseas, and that, as a result, we could borrow money in almost any country abroad. I tell the honorable senator that a person who has something of value is always able to pawn it. It is never difficult to get a dollar from a pawn-broker for a watch worth £20. Any country in the world is prepared to lend money, on Australia's productive capacity. I am sure that if the Government were to ask the people of the United States of America, or of any other overseas country, for a loan the money that would be offered would be almost unlimited, provided that those who lent it could take over the control of Australia, as happened in 1929-30. It was a Labour government that got us out of that financial tangle.
In another paragraph of the Minister's speech he referred to what this Government had done to help those in need. Referring to criticism of the Government in this -connexion, he said -

quote.para: Senator McKenna referred to social services and what this Government did to help those who are in need. It is most unfair ; I will go further and say that it is very cruel ; to use an occasion such as this to lead persons who are necessitous and in poor circumstances to think that, if only a Labour government were in power, their worries would be over and Father Christmas would walk Among them once more. There is nothing more -distasteful than an attempt to capture popular esteem by dwelling on the needs and hardships of the poor.

speech.para: Such a statement from the Leader of the Government in this chamber is unworthy of a man holding such a high office. It shows that invalid and age pensioners are regarded only as a party political football. If supporters of the Government are sincere in their concern for pensioners, they can easily remedy the position, because all they have to do is to give the pensioners some further financial assistance, in which event they would no longer be a political football. I tell the Minister and those who hold similar views that the position of many pensioners to-day is, indeed, perilous. It is not often that I bring forward in this chamber the claims of ex-servicemen and pensioners generally, because I believe that such matters should not be brought forward in order to gain political kudos. I told the pensioners that, but they replied that it was my duty to bring their case before the Senate. It is for that reason that I have done so to-day.

I recall some events that happened in Canberra a fortnight ago to-day. A number of pensioners arrived in Canberra and tried to secure an interview with the Treasurer (Sir Arthur Fadden), but he refused to see them. The delegation then said that if he still refused to see them they would sit on the steps of Parliament House until he changed his mind. I advised them not to do that, and warned them that if they persisted in their intention to remain on the steps all night many of them would be in hospital the next day. They then said that such an action on their part would at least be a demonstration, and might lead to something being done in the future to help others in a similar position. I left them about half past nine, and later Senator Cole went out to them and said, " It is quite all right now, you can go home; I have made representations to the Treasurer and he will see you at 11.30 in the morning". They saw the Treasurer in the morning, and even his casehardened soul was softened after he had heard their representations, because he said, " I am sorry for you and it brings a lump into my throat ". When they told me that, I said to them, " I hope that the lump in his throat is so large that he coughs up something to-night for you when he delivers his budget speech ". But, as honorable senators know, the pensioners received nothing in the budget.

I do not want this matter to be made into a political struggle, but I point out that before the last general election, when the last budget was brought in by the Treasurer, the age pensioners received an increase of pension. However, under this budget, because there is no general election in the offing, the age pensioners have been granted nothing at all. How is it possible for a pensioner to exist on ?4 a week? Of course, I do not say that the Government can continually increase pensions as the years go by; but this Government, or some government, or some authority, should at least prepare a statement for the Parliament outlining a scheme so that in - the future those who have been maimed in industry and those who have worked in industry and reared families and have now become too old to work, will at least be assured of a shelter, a decent bed, a decent meal and a warm fire in cold weather. No party should make party politics of the pensioners' plight, but if the Opposition does not mention it nobody will mention it. Somebody has to put forward their case. About 130,000 people in Melbourne recently signed a petition asking the Treasurer to give favorable consideration to the requests of pensioners. I challenge this Government to resign to-day and face the electors on_ this issue.

talk.start.para: - We shall resign any time that the Opposition desires.
- The Labour party was never more ready to contest an election than it is to-day.
- Who is the leader of the Labour party?

- That is all very well; but the Liberal party has taken into its ranks another derelict of ours in Tasmania. Anything that is derelict falls into the arms of the old Liberal party or the Australian Country party. Anything that is of no more use, or any traitor, falls into the hands of the Liberal party. A member of the Liberal party who is a Minister said to me only to-day, " Good <3od, another one! What is our party coming to? #34;. I said, " It is coming to what it has always been, a rubbish tip for politicians of the type that leave our party ". I say in all sincerity that at least the Government should have given favorable consideration to the representations of the age pensioners. "Will any honorable senator on the Government side stand up and say that the pensioners have not been treated unjustly? Can they go home to-night to their warm beds

speech.para: And really believe that the pensioners have a reasonable standard of living?

talk.start.para: - This Government has treated the pensioners much, better than any Labour government ever did.
- Had it not been for the Labour party the pensioners would be receiving nothing to-day.
- What rot!

- My mind goes back to 1907, when the Labour party had only a handful of representatives in the Australian Parliament. The price that we sought for our support of the Government was that some assistance should be given to aged people, and the aged were granted pensions of 7s. 6d. a week. What did they get in the years before 1907 from governments such as the Government that we have at present? It was the Labour party mat initiated age pensions; and assistance to pensioners has been Labour's platform since it was formed in 1900. Had it not been for the Labour party there would beno age pensions to-day,, and the same type of busybodies would be going round poking their noses into the business of these poor unfortunate persons and saying, " You can have one pound of flour and one pound of sugar for the next week ". That is not the sort of treatment that the workers should get when they are laid aside; but it is the treatment that they got under previous nonLabour governments and the treatment that they would get to-day if there were no Labour party. Fools rush in where angels fear to tread-
- Then why rush?
- The

speech.para: Attorney-General (Senator O'sullivan) has galloped in. He attacked the Leader of the Opposition (Senator McKenna) when he made statements recently about wages. I hope that he does not throw orders about, when he is administering the Navy, as he threw figures about in the Senate recently. If he does so, all our ships, even the old junk that we have got from England, will be on the rocks. The Attorney-General said that when the Chifley Government was in office the basic wage was £4 14s. or £4 15s. That is completely erroneous. The honorable senator discussed the most important matter that confronts this Parliament, that is the wages of the workers, and said that in 1949 the basic wage was £4 14s. or £4 15s. That shows that he does not know what the basic wage was then, because in point of fact it was more than £5 a week in those days. Then, he said that the average wage paid to-day is in the vicinity of £17 a week.

talk.start.para: - What is the basic wage in Tasmania?
- In the

speech.para: Minister's State of Queensland it is £11 15s. a week. But, what is 45s. a week to the Minister, who receives about £6,000 a year? But, 45s. a week is a fortune to the basic wage earner, and at least the honorable senator, who is the Attorney-General, should know what the basic wage was in 1949. I hope that the previous Attorney-General, who is now the Chief Judge of the Commonwealth Industrial Court, knows something more about industry than his successor does. The Minister says the average wage now paid is £17 a week.

talk.start.para: - That is quite true.
- I have the official figures before me, and I inform honorable senators that the maximum amount that a tradesman can earn, with all his allowances and margins for skill, is £17 a week.
- The honorable senator is quite wrong.
- I challenge the Attorney-General to instruct his secretary or his departmental head to obtain the correct figures and then put them before the Senate.
- I have stated the up-to-date figures.
- The figures that I have are up to date, because they have been obtained from the Melbourne Trades Hall. The trades halls are the only places where one finds people interested in the basic wage.
- The honorable senator should go to the Commonwealth Statistician for the correct figures.

- The trades halls in the various capital cities are the only reliable places at which to make inquiries about the conditions and wages of the workers. The Minister has stated that the workers are enjoying great prosperity, but if it were not for the fact that the wives of many workers are also working, the average sum coming into the average home each week would be less than the basic wage. Letter carriers and telephone linemen are taking home in their pay envelopes less than the basic wage. This Government is not prepared to assist the letter carriers although, after 40 years' service in all weathers, they receive the same pay as they were given when they began their service. After 40 years of service to the public, they are still on the same salary. It -is scandalous. This Government should be able to do something for the linemen and the mail staff in the post office.
- What does the honorable senator mean when he says that the letter carriers get the same salary as they did 40 years ago? Will he explain?
- The honorable senator does not have to explain.

- When the little discussion between the Leader of the Government in the Senate and the honorable senator who has wool in his ears has been concluded, I shall make everything clear. I said that if a letter carrier starts in the mailroom at £720 a year, he finishes his service after 40 years on the same salary. There are no increments. The salary varies from time to time, but the letter carrier gets no increments for the service he has rendered to the Postmaster-General's Department.
- The honorable senator wants us to believe that a man who starts on £720 a year gets no increase for 40 years?

- That is correct. He gets the same salary - apart from basic wage and cost of living increases, which are something different. The Leader of the Government said that the Leader of the Opposition (Senator McKenna) had had the temerity to talk about defence, and he said that that bewildered a tolerant fellow like himself. I know that the Leader of the. Government is a tolerant fellow, but he doss not like listening to facts.
- I do not get a chance to hear them from the Opposition.

- I should like the Leader of the Government to answer the points that I- have raised. I fully endorse the statements that have been made by the Leader of the Opposition. If the Government is so sure of its political grounds, it should go to the people before it draws any more red herrings across the trail, and it would get its answer from the electors. It would be oblivion.

. - lt is the right of the Opposition to criticize the budget and any other measure that is introduced by the Government; in fact, it is the bounden duty of the Opposition to criticize the Government's proposals, but those criticisms should be constructive. The speeches that have been made by Senator Hendrickson and other honorable senators on. the Opposition side fell short of that requirement. I am getting very tired of listening, year after year, to Opposition speeches which contain nothing constructive to help us to cope with the tremendous problems that face us. Honorable senators opposite are silent, and that indicates that they acquiesce in my statement. I was particularly disappointed with the speech of the Leader of the Opposition (Senator McKenna), and with the contribution made yesterday by Senator Byrne, from whom we expect something worth while. The Leader of the Opposition did himself less than justice. He spent an hour, and the extra time granted to him by the courtesy of Government supporters, in accusing the Government of low aim.
- We get no courtesy from Government supporters.
- The Leader of the Opposition did get courtesy - we extended his time.
- Only the courtesy to which he is entitled.
- He said that this Government's chief crime was low aim. Does he not realize the unpopular things that this Government has had to do?
- The people realize it.
- Senator Ashley has been saying that for a long time, but the people have not believed him. The Leader of the Opposition said that the only concern of this Government was to keep itself in office.
- That is true.

- Do not the Leader of the Opposition and Senator Hendrickson recall the unpopular things that this Government has had to do? It did not do them for the sake of winning friends. Its efforts have had the opposite effect. The Government has faced up to its problems because it is a responsible government, and is prepared to meet unpopularity. I have only to remind honorable senators opposite of the wool prepayment legislation that enforced prepayment of taxes. The Opposition said that the legislation would be unpopular. How, then, can the Leader of the Opposition say that this Government is concerned only with retaining office? What about the so-called horror budget of 1951? Was that calculated to keep the Government in office? What about the import restrictions which are a tremendous hardship on people in business? Are they calculated to win friends and influence people? I remind the Opposition of the present credit restriction. How can the Leader of the Opposition claim that this Government's only concern is to keep itself in office? If the Leader of the Opposition did not say that, I ask him to correct me now. His statement that the Government was guilty of low aim was unworthy of him.
- Your opinions do not count for much.

- Perhaps the opinion of the people has more weight. They have expressed themselves in support of this Government four times, much to the chagrin of the Opposition. Winning a battle against inflation is not easy or spectacular, lt is most likely to be achieved by unpopular means, but that has not daunted the Government. Nobody knows the difficulties of the Government better than does the Leader of the Opposition, who was a Minister in a previous administration. He knows that circumstances vary constantly. Many fluctuating factors affect the economy. Does not the Leader of the Opposition remember, for example, that according to the C series index, the cost of living had already risen twice before the Labour Government went out of office. In 1948, it rose by 8.9 per cent, and, in 1949, by 9.8 per cent. That was a total increase of nearly 19 per cent, in the two last years of the previous Government's regime Inflation had already begun. We have been trying to combat it ever since.

speech.para: Does not the Leader of the Opposition remember the basic wage increase of £1 a week granted by the Commonwealth Court of Conciliation and Arbitration, in 1950, and the effect it had upon the economy? Does he not remember the violent upsurge of prices for our exports overseas in 1951? Those prices were of tremendous benefit to the industries concerned, but they have had a big impact on the economy because of the sudden influx of fresh money from outside. Does not he also remember the demand for imports from abroad which that influx of fresh money created? None of those things was present when this Government took office. Does the Leader of the Opposition remember the Korean war, or does he forget it? It cannot be said that that was expected when the Government came into office. We cannot forget the effects of it and the tremendous strain it imposed upon Australia internally. Does not the Leader of the Opposition remember the tremendous and continued demand by the people of this country for expansion of one sort and another, the tremendous and natural demand for homes, schools, hospitals, office accommodation, buildings of all kinds, public works and, last but not least, increased social services?

Here, I should like to remind the Senate that in this year of grace, under this very budget, the Government is providing for a record expenditure on social services of £226,000,000. That is one-fifth of the total budget expenditure. In other words, £1 of every £5 which this Government will collect this year is to be spent on social services. The same thing can be said of the defence requirements of the country. This year £190,000,000 is to be spent, and during the last six years an average population of 8,500,000 people has provided £1,000,000,000 for defence. That works out at £12 per head expenditure on defence during the six years this Government has been in office. Most of that expenditure is non-productive and highly inflationary. It is unforeseen and unpredictable.

talk.start.para: - And justifiable.

- Yes; and I think the people of Australia accept that proposition. I come back to what I said just now. The Leader of the Opposition, as a Minister in a preceding Administration, knows these things better than does any one else, yet he accuses this Government not only of failure, but of low aim, making no allowance for the effect of these things on our economy. He seeks to make miserable party political capital out of the difficulties of the day.

speech.para: He made a remarkable statement which I cannot accept. Generally, I expect great things from the Leader of the Opposition, but this statement was not worthy of him. I remind him - and this must be particularly galling to him - that this Government has been to the country on several occasions. The Opposition challenged us to go to the country, and we went sooner than our opponents relished. In 1951, the people supported us. In 1954* we achieved a similar result. In 1955, after several years of office, the people of Australia sent the Menzies Government back into the House of Representatives with a tremendously increased majority, and in this place we won five out of the six States, something that had never been done before. We very nearly won all six States, lt was a tremendous victory and, surely, an endorsement by the people of Australia, if one were needed, of the policy this Government has been pursuing. It has introduced unpopular measures, but the people of Australia realize that we have a high sense of responsibility; and, after all, they have experienced unprecedented prosperity, full employment and a security of which they never dreamed.

A great deal has been said in this debate about the quarterly cost of living adjustments of the basic wage. We have heard: a good deal from both sides as to the wisdom of certain States restoring those adjustments after the Arbitration Court had: suspended them in 1953. We have been told by some honorable senators opposite that the Government has frozen wages. Nohonorable senator can be sincere in making that statement, because he knows that it is not the truth. The court suspended quarterly adjustments in 1953, and, as I have said, certain States have seen fit to restore them. A notable exception is the action of the Premier of the State which I have the honour to represent, South Australia, and I am glad to see that other States are following his good record in this regard, including Victoria, according to reports in this morning's press. What we fail to realize is that the action of certain States in restoring the quarterly adjustments has actually defeated any chance we had of achieving stability in our economy.

It is rather ironical to consider the statements of some Labour leaders both inside and outside this chamber. Before the suspension of quarterly cost of living adjustments, statements were made by prominent trade union leaders criticizing their continuance. I have not time to read all those statements, but I shall give the Senate the names of some of the gentlemen who made them and the dates on which they were made so that they can be checked. On 23rd October, 1951, a statement was made by Mr. Albert Monk, whose name is a household word in Australia and who is recognized as being one of the sanest presidents of the Australian Council of Trades Unions. He said -

quote.para: Each rise in the nominal wage due to quarterlyadjustments seriously lowered the value of skilled' workers' margins.

speech.para: Then, Mr. Cahill, on 18th April, 1952. had this to say -

quote.para: Every time the wage goes up prices rise to a new peak. In the final check, wage-earners are worse off. This is an endless spiral ending in frustration. It is demoralizing to our economy and is undermining rural and industrial stability.

speech.para: That statement was made by the Premier of New South Wales, but he has since seen fit. to restore the quarterly adjustments in his own State and, to-day, he refuses to back down on that issue. 1 believed Mr. Cahill the first time, and most people did also. I have copies of similar statements made by trade union leaders and responsible people outside the Parliament, and I accept what they have said on that subject.

Let us now trace the history of quarterly adjustments and consider some figures in regard to the effect of their restoration. In 1951, after the £1 a week basic wage rise was granted by the court, the cost of living, as shown by the C series price index went up by approximately 19 per cent. In 1952, there was a further rise, of 20 per cent. In 1953 - and this is. interesting because it followed the suspension of the quarterly adjustments - the. rise was only 3.8 per cent. We almost achieved stability. In 1954s. the rise was only 1.4 per cent. Those are very significant figures. In 1956, after five States restored the quarterly adjustments, the cost of living rose immediately by 6 per cent.

talk.start.para: - Give, the Senate some figures about the rise in profits.

- Senator Cook interjected something about profits. That is another matter altogether. I shall address myself to that subject if Senator Cooke will give me time. At this juncture, I am pointing out the effect of quarterly adjustments on the cost of living as shown by the C series index. I agree with the proposition that there is a crying need for some system of uniformity between the Commonwealth and the States in regard to wage fixation. I agree also with the statement made by the Minister for National Development (Senator Spooner) the other night. I quote him. He is always worth quoting, by the way, and on this occasion particularly so. He said -

quote.para: There is much to be gained from a substantial unity throughout Commonwealth and State jurisdictions in the principles and practices of wage determination.

speech.para: This must be achieved if the present chaos is to be eliminated. We must all accept the principle advocated last night by Senator Wright that regard must be had, in the fixation of wages, to the ability ot industry to pay. That is about the most sensible and constructive statement that has been made during this debate. In 1951-52, after the tremendous rise of wool prices, the Arbitration Court quite rightly awarded a prosperity loading, based on the ability of the industry to pay h. Do honorable senators opposite say thai that was not a proper principle to observe then? I consider that it was right that the workers who shore the sheep should enjoy some of the profits gained from the prices then current.

talk.start.para: - The last price paid for wool was a record, but the shearers are now receiving lower wages.

- The last price was not a record, which shows how much Senator Cooke does not know about this subject. A couple of years ago the price averaged J20d.; this season it was down to 60d. Does the honorable senator refute that fact? When the Queensland Industrial Court made an award for the shearing industry in Queensland last year, it recognized partially the fall in wool prices, but because the rate of wage was accordingly lower shearers all over Queensland have gone on strike, and the current wool sales in Brisbane' have been threatened. I wish that people engaged in industry, both employers and employees, would agree to accept a wage based on the maximum ability of industry to pay. 1 would be content with that at any time, and it is a principle which must be observed in the system of wage fixing. But when a court makes an award, no threat should be made by any government, either Commonwealth or State, to countermand it. It is deplorable that after a court has expressed itself in regard to quarterly adjustments, its decision should be countermanded by the action of certain States.

speech.para: In regard to the raising of loan money in Australia J endorse Senator Wright's comment that the taxpayers cannot continue to provide, through taxation, about £200,000,000 a year to be spent on Commonwealth and State public works in order to make up the short-fall in. loan raisings. The taxpayers should not be asked to do that. According to this budget they will contribute £100,000,000 in taxation for the Commonwealth's own public works programme, and about £109,000,000 of the estimated budget surplus will be rebated to the States to enable them to carry on wilh their loan works programme. If the taxpayers are asked to contribute either this or a smaller amount to make up the short fall in loan raisings, they should be given some acknowledgment by the Treasury of the amount so contributed. If this amount is to be raised it should be regarded as a form of compulsory saving, and the contributor should be entitled to receive some increment for investment. In normal times, public works would be financed from loan moneys, the taxpayer would be called upon to pay interest and the bondholder would receive his interest. The taxpayers who contribute this sum of £200,000,000 are in a most invidious position. They are called upon to make direct tax contributions to the Treasury to this extent, a portion of which is rebated to the States. The States are charged interest, and the poor unfortunate taxpayer again pays his share of interest on that money also, and again on sinking fund payments. He should not be expected to continue on that basis.

In the light of present conditions, a system of priority should be applied to public works, both Commonwealth and State. I know that the Commonwealth has put a proposition to the States which certain Premiers have rejected, but in view of the fact that the expenditure of loan money on public works is, in many ways, inflationary, the Commonwealth should proceed, with those works which have the highest priority and set a better example than it has done in this budget. Certain States must also show more sense of responsibility in regard to loan expenditure. It is all very well for them to sit back and say that they would do much more if the Commonwealth would give them the money. A degrading and appalling stage has been reached in Commonwealth and State financial relations.

Everything possible must be done to make investments in Commonwealth securities more attractive. In this budget the Government might have increased the 2s. tax rebate. I am not suggesting what it should be, but an increase would have encouraged people to invest. There are counterattractions for the investment of what money is available. I should not like to see the interest rate raised, and I am confident that the loan market could be made more attractive. I agree with Senator Laught that the Government should accept Commonwealth securities at their face value, in satisfaction of Commonwealth estate duty, provided that those securities have been held for a stipulated period of three or four years. The States also should play ball in regard to their succession duties, and this would be an inducement to investors to put their money into Commonwealth loans.

I wish that the States would tackle the matter of hire purchase, which is a direct competitor with loan investment.- I am not attacking the hire-purchase system, because I have bought many necessary articles under hire-purchase agreement. Hire-purchase business, however, offers unfair competition to loan raisings, because articles can be purchased without deposit. That is a trap, a snare and a delusion for the person who signs the hire-purchase agreement, and it is a type of business which should not be allowed. The same criticism applies to the purchase of articles on very low deposits. According to the press reports of the Victorian Premier's budget speech, Victoria is tackling this problem, and time alone will show whether its method will be successful. The States should all tackle this problem, in their own interest as well as in the interests of persons who sign hire-purchase agreements and of the country as a whole.

Senator Benn made certain statements in his speech, which, I am confident, he will, upon reflection, regret. I hope that when opportunity offers he may correct the impression which he made. According to the " Hansard " report of his speech he said -

quote.para: The primary producers of Australia are falling down on their responsibilities and obligations to the people.

speech.para: He was referring to the shortage in the production of potatoes. He went on -

quote.para: They have the land and equipment to produce potatoes, but they do not produce them.

speech.para: I shall leave my colleague, Senator Mattner, to deal with the subject of potatoes, because he grows them, but I want to take Senator Benn to task for his general statement that the primary producers of Australia have let this country down. If he cares to examine some appropriate figures he will find that primary production has increased in volume, and is still increasing. The tragedy of the whole thing is that values for these products are falling lower and lower; but the primary producers themselves have done a marvellous job over the last few years in lifting their production, as the figures for wheat, barley and other primary products will show.

Senator Benn implied that this Government had given certain hand-outs to the wheat-growers. He ought to know that the legislation to which he referred was introduced by a Labour government. We have simply improved it, and carried it on for a further term. Actually, if anybody has got anything out of that legislation it has been the consumers of Australia who have benefited to the extent of at least £150,000,000 during the eight years it has been in operation. If wheat had been sold in Australia for all purposes at export parity, the wheat-growers would have received at least £150,000,000 more than they did, and the consumers would have paid that much more. I have much pleasure in supporting the motion and opposing the amendment.

talk.start.para: . - Senator Pearson, like all other speakers on the Government side, has criticized the Leader of the Opposition (Senator McKenna) and appealed for some constructive thought. As this request has been repeated by almost every speaker from the Government side, it indicates to me that the Government is sorely in need of sound advice; and I assure Senator Pearson that by the time I have completed my remarks the Government will have received such advice. He attacked Senator Benn for his statement about primary producers, but he failed to tell the Senate that although the average production of wheat per acre has increased from 13 to 15 bushels in the last five years and, last year, reached the record yield of 19 bushels, there has been no reduction in the price of bread to the consumer. Senator Pearson is concerned only about the producers; he gives no thought at all to the consumers.

speech.para: I congratulate Senator Buttfield on the excellent speech she delivered last night when she traced the history of the Snowy Mountains hydro-electric scheme. She certainly gave us some interesting details. She told us of what the River Murray Commission was doing to mitigate floods. I always understood that the main purpose of that commission was to apply water to the land for irrigation purposes. She also suggested the setting-up of more commissions and boards. In that respect, she certainly qualified for No. 1 position on the bandwagon. She admitted, however, that the Snowy Mountains hydro-electric scheme was initiated by a Labour government in co-operation with the Governments of Victoria arid New South Wales. But she failed to tell us - probably this was because she was not in the Parliament at the time and, therefore, was not aware of the fact - that the Liberal and Country parties boycotted the official opening of that scheme. If she had brought out those facts during the course of her excellent speech, the true picture would have been presented to the public.

Senator Marriott joined in the constant appeal from the Government side for small investors to contribute to Government loans. He suggested that some provision should be made for collecting this money from those people; but I remind him that many financial interests, such as trust and investment companies, are paying higher rates of interest to-day, and the small investor is just as entitled as is the large investor to place his capital in the most lucrative market.

Many opinions have been expressed about the budget, but the most effective condemnation of it and of the fiscal policy of the Menzies-Fadden Administration will not be heard in the Senate or in another place, but outside where it has been condemned most effectively by the people who contribute most to our national development, the primary producers, manufacturers, business people and workers of the community. During this debate it has become more apparent than ever that the Menzies-Fadden Administration is absolutely incapable of coping with- the deepening economic crisis facing Australia or with the problems which are disrupting our economy and lowering the standards of the Australian people. Never in the history of responsible government has Australia lacked guidance or national leadership as much as it does to-day.

Some weeks ago, the Acting Prime Minister (Sir Arthur Fadden) called a conference of Premiers in Canberra for the purpose of attempting to arrive at a means of stemming the tide of inflation. He sought to place the responsibility for introducing controls for this purpose solely upon the State

Premiers, but his ruse failed completely. Even the conservative Premiers of South Australia and Victoria, Messrs. Playford and Bolte; joined with the Labour Premiers of the other States in unanimously rejecting the proposals put forward by the right honorable gentleman. Prior to the calling of that conference, the federal executive of the Liberal party had become alarmed at the rapid deterioration in the economy of this country. So disturbed were those gentlemen that they warned the members of the Parliamentary Liberal party that the basic philosophy of the party was supposed to be opposed to controls. This is somewhat ironical when one considers the number of controls that were imposed some time ago and which are still in operation. The concern of the Liberal party and the action taken by it were unnecessary and a waste of effort. It was wasted for this reason: The controls that the Menzies Government proposed to introduce, if it could obtain the support and co-operation of the State Premiers, were in relation to wages and the freezing of the cost of living adjustments, both of which had been imposed previously by this Government, in accordance with the policies of the Liberal and Australian Country parties. The truth of the matter is that the Menzies-Fadden Administration and its supporters are unwilling to deal properly with an economy that has been allowed to run to seed. All that this Government has offered to the people of Australia have been the conflicting counsels of despair that have emerged from the Cabinet room, in the shape of the control of wages and the freezing of the cost of living adjustments, supported by a spate of advice from advisers and others who advocate a state of economic anarchy, which they arc pleased to label a basic philosophy.

talk.start.para: - From what is the honorable senator reading?

- -I am not reading as much as Senator Wright did during a certain debate recently, and I hope that he is not so bored as I was on that occasion. The cardinal principle on which they agree is that nothing must be done to disturb the plunderers and the profiteers. The Menzies Government is in a position to call on a panel of political professors to prescribe policies which are as objectionable to the Labour party as was Labour's policy of full employment to the tories led by the Prime Minister (Mr. Menzies). There is now a team of professors on the prowl, who adjust their economic and financial theories, according to the complexion of the government in office. In the past, they were not slow to see virtue in what has been loosely described as doctrinaire socialism, but today they are the white-haired wonders of the Menzies Government. Indeed, they were responsible for advising the Acting Prime Minister (Sir Arthur Fadden) to call the Canberra conference to consider another Premiers' plan, the victims of which would be the workers and the people in the lower income ranges. Already, there are signs of an economic crisis, due to the hit or miss, policy of this Government.

speech.para: Sir Frank Richardson, who is the president of the Australian Council of Retailers,, and a confidant of this Government, said in a statement a few weeks ago that therehad been seven major changes in the financial policy of this Government during the last four years. What hope can there be for either economic security or a measure of national development when so many capricious changes of policy are made?

talk.start.para: - There have been no capricious changes of policy.

- Owing to the restrictive fiscal policy of the Government, and the restriction of imports, thousands of workers, in this country have lost their employment. I now am coming to a subject that might: interest the interjector.
- Interjector?

- Despite the questionable propaganda that was disseminated by the Minister for National Development (Senator Spooner) during last week-end, due to the financial controls imposed by this Government there has been a marked decline of home building. According to the quarterly bulletin of New South Wales building statistics recently released by the Bureau of Statistics and Economics, permits for buildings to cost £152,349,000 were issued during the last financial year. Only 25,527 of the permits were for new houses, and flats, the third lowest total since the war. The numbers represented a fall of 12,461 when compared with 37,988 permits issued.' in 1950-51.

speech.para: When speaking over the air last Sunday, the Minister referred continually to a drop of 2,000 in the number of houses. He has since been reported in the press to that effect. How does the Minister reconcile his assertion that there has only been a drop of 2,000 in the number of new houses and flats a year with the fact that the number of permits issued for these buildings was 12,000 lower last year than in 1950-51? The Minister endeavours to mislead both this chamber and the people of Australia when he says that this Government is annually increasing housing accommodation for home-seekers, including immigrants.

talk.start.para: - If the honorable senator reads a statement that will be published in to-morrow's press, he will be able to get up to date on this subject.

- The Minister employs a snide method of deception. He says that percentage figures, based upon production and the capital cost of buildings, reveal an increase of home-building activity, but in fact, owing to the Government's restrictive financial policy, there has been a serious fall in home-building. His analysis of the housing position, as late as the last week-end, conveniently overlooked the main factor which has led to a recession in the building trade. The undoubted cause of the shortage of housing accommodation has been the restriction of finance for home building for both private persons and State housing authorities. Not only has finance for home building become more difficult to obtain, but also the rate of interest has steadily risen because of action taken by the Commonwealth Government. I do not think that the Minister for National Development will deny that, or that the result is that the average home seeker is placed at a great disadvantage and finds the utmost difficulty in obtaining a home.

speech.para: The Minister claims that in spite of the reduction by 20 per cent, in the first two years and by 30 per cent, in the succeeding three years of the money allocated to the Housing Commission of New South Wales and the granting of more money to cooperative building societies, the number of homes built will be increased. That is absolutely false reasoning, because not one more house will be built as a result of the action of the Government. I agree that over a long term of years there will be some gain, so far as the co-operative societies areconcerned, because their loan terms are much shorter, with the result that the money will be turned over more quickly. That isa long-distance plan, but it makes no provision whatever for the distress that exists to-day because of the lack of houses. That shortage is solely the responsibility of theMenzies Government, because of its neglect to provide necessary finance for home building. Some indication of the position, as it relates to co-operative building societies in New South Wales will be seen, from the fact that whereas, on 31st March, 1952, they had 11,175 subscribers who hadprovided £17,523,290 for the purchase of homes, on 31st March, 1956, there wereonly 4,942 subscribers who had provided £12,066,780. Those figures are significant, despite the inflationary state of Australia's finances. They reveal a drop in the number of subscribers, and of over £5,000,000, in a period of four years. Those figures do not take into account the inflated state of our currency to-day. According to the " Sydney Morning Herald " of 8th September, 1956, the vice-president of the Real Estate Institute, Mr. Daniel Currie, isreported to have said that the central bank should make more money available for home building. The report in the- " Sydney Morning Herald " of his statement continues -

quote.para: Building material production was at a record level, labour was plentiful and building costs, were steady.

speech.para: That is true -

quote.para: The bank should act now and assist the trading, banks to make finance available. A great deal more than the few millions now being made available by the new private savings banks is needed.

speech.para: He went on to say -

quote.para: Co-operative building societies have a waiting., list of 25,000; war service homes 13,000, and the Housing Commission another 25,000. With such lucrative rates of interest offered by many large Sydney companies to the general public, the amount of mortgage money available from this hitherto good source is now negligible. Never before has there been greater need for finance from the banking authorities.

speech.para: That last remark applies also to the Government's financial policy. Many thousands of Australian families are waiting for housing, accommodation; yet the housing authorities, throughout Australia admit their inability to- provide them with even emergency accommodation. The result is that thousands of people are living 'in emergency huts, garages and tents. They are waiting in vain for success in housing ballots. Others are living in tents and caravans on building allotments that they have bought, and although they have finance ranging from £500 to more than £1,000 there is no authority, either governmental or private, which is prepared to provide the balance of the finance necessary to enable them to construct homes on their holdings.

Many ex-servicemen are in a similar position. They have to wait for two years for approval and final action in connexion with a loan from the War Service Homes Division. A few days ago I referred to the group building system, but my remarks were treated with derision by the Minister, to the delight of some of the cheer squad sitting behind him. Under that system, until recently a deposit of £250 was required from an ex-serviceman seeking a home of three bedrooms, but now he is asked to put down a deposit of £750. What is the reason for the change? I" know that there is inflation in this country, but I did not think that it had galloped that fast. If an ex-serviceman requires a two-bedroom home, he is asked to put down a deposit of about £650. Moreover, the conditions under which he now obtains a home are completely different from the conditions under which a home was made available when the deposit was £250. Previously, an ex-serviceman could choose a home that had been finished, or. could select one that was partly complete. At present, he is shown plans of fourteen houses, and after he has selected one, he has to put down his deposit of £750. However, his trouble does not end there, because he has to wait until £750 has been deposited in respect of each of the fourteen homes before the construction of any one of the houses is started. Therefore, with a group of fourteen homes, approximately £10,000 is collected from ex-servicemen before one brick is laid. It seems as if the ex-servicemen themselves are practically financing the group homes system.

I have been impressed by the fact that almost every speaker in this debate from the Government side has blamed increased wages for the inflation with, which we are afflicted, and they have advocated that wages should be reduced. A few weeks ago the

Minister for Immigration (Mr. Harold Holt) delivered a statement in which he said that it was true that the Government had imposed some restrictions last March, but they were working out just as had been planned. He said that those restrictions had not been imposed to create a depression, but to consolidate our prosperity. What a statement! I cannot understand how our prosperity is being consolidated while thousands of people are losing their employment. The best prosperity that we can have is to have a state of affairs in which every man who wants to work is able to get it. The Minister for Primary Industry (Mr. McMahon) also delivered a statement on the same day as the Minister for Immigration, and he said that there are ups and downs in every economy. Unfortunately, there are too many downs in our economy. He also said that the fact that the economy has regressed a little will not prove to be harmful, and that we should have to produce more, and produce it more efficiently. Again, the workers have to suffer. The economic backwoodsmen in the Government cannot talk of any one except the workers, and they blame the workers for all the disruption that has occurred in our economy. Any measures taken by the Menzies Government are taken only in an effort to cure our economy of the ills and ailments that this Government is responsible for creating.

Recently, a most outrageous appointment was made to the Commonwealth Industrial Court. I repeat that the appointment of Senator Spicer as Chief Judge of the newly created Commonwealth Industrial Court is a political outrage. Senator Spicer drafted the recent industrial legislation for the Government, and piloted it through the Senate, and now he has been given the job of administering it. Surely he will administer it in a party political fashion. The Opposition will be disappointed if he does not! Why did he not disclose to the Senate that he would be an applicant for the position of Chief Judge? Because if he had done so, he would have disqualified himself from presenting the bill to the Senate! We appear to have gone back to the 1920's when Judge Lukin, Judge Drake-Brockman and Judge Dethridge were on the Bench, and when there was what might be called political arbitration, which caused industrial disturbances.

I am sorry that Senator Spicer finished up in the way that he did because it is outrageous for the Government to make such an appointment. That appointment will not bring any confidence to the industrial movement. We hear many wails and claims from some honorable senators on the Government side as they appeal to us for a suggestion to cure our economic ills. If it were not for the fact that there is something wrong with our economy there would be no appeals from the Government for such suggestions. I support the amendment moved by the Leader of the Opposition, and I hope that it is carried.

talk.start.para: .- I join with my colleague, Senator Pearson, in expressing regret at the contribution made to this debate by the Leader of the Opposition (Senator McKenna). I look for something better than was put before us in this debate by the honorable senator. I took the trouble of looking through the major speeches that Senator McKenna has made in this chamber during the last few years, and after my secretary had obtained them all for me, I said, " Why did you cut out so many? If you had cut out the first one, it would have been all that I required, because all the speeches are the same". In all those speeches Senator McKenna referred to Amalgamated Wireless (Australasia) Limited, to the Commonwealth Oil Refineries Limited, or to the Australian Whaling Commission. Moreover, all his references to those bodies were along the same lines.

speech.para: However, in the speech that he delivered in this debate I noticed that the Government is no longer accused of wrecking the Commonwealth Bank, apparently because the bank has made such great profits under this Government that not even Senator McKenna has the hide to charge us with trying to wreck it. Indeed, according to the press this morning, the Commonwealth Bank has made a profit of £4,400,000. That, honorable senators should remember, is the institution that Senator McKenna said in the past we are trying to wreck. In the face of the evidence of the bank's stability, even Senator McKenna has discovered that he must cease his attacks on the Government about its alleged wrecking of the Commonwealth Bank.

The honorable senator has also veered off his course about the sale of Commonwealth ships. For some years he maintained that the Government intended to give the ships away. Now he has changed his course, and says that the Government has passed legislation which will make it possible for private shipping lines to dominate the coastal shipping of this country. 1 commend him for dropping his attacks on the Government about these two matters, and suggest that there are other matters that he could well drop. We make no bones about selling government enterprises. Ever since 1949 we have stated clearly to the people of Australia that it is our policy to sell these undertakings. On that policy the people elected the present Government, and has re-elected it several times. Therefore, we have every right to believe that the people approve our policy.

The Opposition should also remember that the Government made a good deal in selling its undertakings. Any one who looks at the record, particularly the share values a few months after we sold the Commonwealth share holdings in Amalgamated Wireless (Australasia) Limited, will find that the. Government did a good stroke of business.

We make our policy clear. What does the Australian Labour party do? I turn to the booklet, "The Light Glows Brighter ", the new policy for the Australian Labour party which has been produced by Dr. John Burton with a foreword by the federal president of the Australian Labour party and an introduction by the Leader of the Opposition in the House of Representatives (Dr. Evatt), who has stated, in effect, that " this is a course for action ". At page 22 of this great production, Dr. Burton has made this statement with reference to government enterprise^ -

quote.para: This should, of course, be done gradually by bringing under parliamentary control the production of key raw materials such as coal and steel, the operation of national transport by land, sea and air, and the institutions of finance such as banks and insurance companies.

talk.start.para: - What is wrong with that?

- That is all right. There is nothing wrong with it. I hope the Opposition sticks to that policy, because the people will throw it so far away from office that it will not get back into office as a government for twenty years. 1 hope the Australian Labour party sticks to the nationalization of banking, but why does it not tell the people about its policy?
- I have been telling the people for 50 years.
- Yes, but they would not believe you until you tried to put it into effect, and then they kicked you out. I wish to refer now to the continual references by the Leader of the Opposition-
- He is the best man to hold his office for many years. He is a brilliant man.

- He is a good man, but it is a pity he is getting so dreary. He referred continually to taxation policy, but he. did not get down to the true basis of taxation. The Leader of the Opposition persists in referring to the quantum of taxation instead of rates of taxation. I should like to challenge his figures. Total tax collections in the past three years were -

speech.para: That was an increase of £133,000,000 in three years. Those figures are correct in relation to the quantum of tax collections, but what about the national income in the same three years? Let us examine the figures because the comparison is fair although the Leader of the Opposition skips away from it at every opportunity. The national income in the same three years was -

Thus, in three years, there was an increase of £476,000,000 in the national income. What counts in this world is the wealth that is left over, and if we deduct the additional taxes from the increase of national income in the past three years, we find that the people had £343,000,000 more left to them. The Opposition is. afraid to cite those figures.

Where does that money come from? We hear criticism of company profits, but they should be compared with wages, and the, figures for the past three years are available to everybody for comparison. Company profits in the past three years were -
The increase in the three years was £72,000,000. The wages bill for the same three years was -

The increase was £378,000,000 compared with an increase of £72,000,000 in company profits, and £343,000,000 extra was left in the hands of the community after additional taxes had been paid. Those figures cannot be refuted because they are. in the White Paper that was published by the Government. It is interesting to study, in this context, what the taxation policy of the Australian Labour party is likely to be. I turn again to the great book, " The Light Glows Brighter " because, after all, it has a foreword by the federal president of the Labour party and an introduction by the Leader of the Opposition in the House of Representatives, who has said, in the introduction, that the book " is designed to suggest positive action ". This is the Labour party's policy on taxation as contained in " The Light Glows Brighter " -

quote.para: The basic essential is far higher, and far more progressive personal income tax. . . .

speech.para: Why does not the Opposition tell the people these things? Why do not honorable senators opposite rise and say, " We stand for far higher taxes than those imposed at present "?

talk.start.para: - Not for higher taxes on the workers, but upon those who can afford to pay.
-I have noted that I shall read on and give the Opposition a fair go. This book states -

quote.para: The basic essential is far higher, and far more progressive personal income tax, with greater exemptions on lower incomes. Furthermore, income tax should be based on personal real income.. . .

speech.para: If the Opposition would tell the people of Australia that it believes in higher taxes, the people would know where the Australian Labour party stands. We do not hear statements to that effect from the Opposition. It is very silent on this subject.

Let me direct my attention now to the budget. It refers to the necessity forus to expand our exports. There is only one way in which, we, as a nation,, can get away from import, restrictions: - we can export ourselves oat of them. Except for the private enterprise country - the United States of America - which has money to lend, the world is hungry for capital. Great expansion has. taken place in India, China, West Germany and the Argentine, to mention a few of the rnajor countries of the world, and they have been trying to get capital wherever it is available so that they can increase industrial production. With, that trend, in addition to the expansion in Australia and Great Britain, it is not difficult to understand why there is a shortage of capital throughout the world. We need at least £.1,000,000,000 worth of exports; a year to cope with the demand within Australia for imports.

talk.start.para: - We need that to pay for our imports.

- That is true. That is our target, and we must achieve it. We rely upon our rural producers to obtain most of that export income. One of the tragedies that was mentioned by Senator Wright in his excellent speech last night is the decrease in the income of the rural producers of Australia. It has dropped by £105,000,000 in three years. That is a danger point in our economy. The people upon whom we rely almost entirely for income to pay for our imports have had their income reduced in three years by £105,000,000 owing to falling prices and rising costs.

speech.para: I shall suggest one; or two ways in which wecan increase our exports. I had the great privilege, (during the recess, of visiting some of the countries to our near north. Having been 40 years a trader, naturally my mind and my eye turned, as I wandered through those lands, towards the possibility of Australia's developing a trade with those countries. A land that we have neglected' is the Philippines, which has 20,000,000 people.

talk.start.para: - There are1,000,000,000 in China.
-I did not get to China; no doubt that will come in time.

speech.para: There are 20,000,000 people in the Philippines, which is very close to us, and in the years gone by they have been good customer for our flour and beef. We have had the opportunity to export our flour to the Philippines but have neglected it. As we did have a substantial trade in flour, when I came back I brought this matter to the attention of the Department of Trade and asked a series; of questions. I asked why we were losing our trade with the Philippines to Canada and. the United States of America.. The Department replied that Canada supplies high protein flour,, and the United- States and Australia relatively low protein. Australian flour is,, therefore, directly competitive- with American but not with Canadian.I completely disagree with that departmental thinking. The. valuable trade of Canada with the Philippines at the present time is in high protein flour, and yet no better high protein wheat is grownin the world than that grown in northern New South Wales and in Queensland. If the farmers of northern New South Wales and Queensland were given the incentive to grow high protein wheat, and if we were to get away from this stupidnon-segregation of wheat whereby we put everything into " fair average quality " we would be able to. capture at a profitable level the specialist markets that should be ours.

talk.start.para: - Honorable senators opposite comprise the Government and have done so for seven years.
- Just listen a little, whileI talk about this. I am not playing at a political level, I want to say something that is of use to the nation. Let us for the moment forget about politics.
- Tell what you have to say to your caucus.

- I am telling it to the Senate and it is my right to do. so. If we give an incentive to the farmers of northern New South Wales and Queensland, and interest the wheat-growers and millers of- those areas,, and, at the same time, develop a shipping, service from Queensland ports, as the nearest ports to the Philippines, we have a grand opportunity to regain a great part of that Philippine trade in flour, particularly in high protein flour, because nowhere else in the world can wheat-growers match the. colour of. Australian flour. I suggest that we could sell, to the Philippines 150,000 tons of flour a year and that would be little because their total consumption is in the region of 275,000 tons. We could capture at least 150,000 tons of that trade if we were to go out for it. One thing we do not do in Australia is go to our customers and say " What are you using? We will grow that for you and provide the stuff you want". Our attitude is, "This is what we grow, you take it or leave it ".

speech.para: We spent eight or nine days in Formosa and another 10,000,000 customers exist in the Republic of Free China in Formosa. What a different approach they have towards trade! I discussed trade with them quite a lot. They buy butter and wool tops from us and they also provide a good market for milk products, the things we in Australia want to sell. They get their butter via Hong Kong at the moment, but complain that they do not get a continuity of supply. That is something we should look at. We have no trade commissioner there. I think we should have a trade commissioner wherever we can do trade. In turn, they want to sell us tea, and this is the point I want to talk to honorable senators about, because I think it is of great importance. They do not say, " We grow Chinese tea, therefore you have to take that tea ". I said to them, " We in Australia consume very little of the Chinese type of tea and, therefore, I do not think there would be a good market for it ". They replied, " Ah, we know the tea you want. We have imported seed from India and are growing the black Assam tea that you use in your market, because we want part of your trade. If we want part of your trade we have to grow what you want ". That is the proper customer consideration.

I know that at the present time it would be difficult to develop a large trade because of the deficit in our cash balances. We would have to come down to barter, but what is wrong with a good bit of healthy barter with good people? And make no mistake, these people are good people; they know what they are about. I should like to spend a minute or two of the time at my disposal in talking about the trip we had and the people we met. I approached this trip to Formosa with a perfectly open mind. I have heard honorable senators opposite say certain things, just as I heard one say just now in very derogatory terms, " Chiang

Kai-shek ". 1 went to have a look at this place. Having read the propaganda that has been put out in Australia, 1 thought that we would go into a dictator land and that we would see great banners of Chiang Kai-shek everywhere and all the flapdoodle one sees in dictatorship countries. Nothing was further from the truth. We never saw one photograph, one statue or one banner. Everywhere we went it was Sun Yat Sen, the Father of the Republic. That is what greatly impressed me. This was no dictatorship, this was a country which was setting up a proper republic.
