Then, 1 had a look at the systems of elections. They have universal suffrage of all over twenty years of age. I had read that the mainland Chinese under General Chiang Kai-shek had gone to Formosa, had squatted on this land, and were ruling it with military dictatorship. I found that of the 55 members of the elected Nationalist Assembly 52 are native-born Chinese of Taiwan or Formosa and that only three are mainlanders. I found that in the constitution of this republic 10 per cent, of the members of the Nationalist Assembly, must, by law, be women. I am sure that our women senators will appreciate that fact. I found that their system of local government sets an example to the world and certainly to Australia. In Australia election results show that throughout the continent we have 25 per cent, and 30 per cent, polls, but in Formosa the local government polls amount to 94 per cent, and 97 per cent, when the people are electing their prefectural chairmen, or as we call them, wardens of municipalities. Of the 23 elected on that island 21 are native Taiwanese, or Formosans, and two only are from the mainland. How can any one substantiate that there is a military dictatorship over this island when there are freely conducted elections for everybody to go and see? Results show what is happening. Any suggestion that a military dictatorship exists in Formosa is a complete myth.

I was very interested and was quite frank in speaking to them. From what I had gathered I felt that the government which had gone from the mainland of China was a government that had been full of graft. I had heard that suggested in this chamber and I put it to them. They frankly admitted that, in the disintegration of China, after ten years of fighting the Japanese, after the revolution, and following the Communist and Kuomintang wars, some of the " wise guys " of the Government traded with the enemy and did all sorts of things, and were able to get their money out to America. " But ", they said, " those who did that are either living in America to-day or they were shot on the mainland of China. They are not in Formosa ". These were little pointers which were eloquent of the high moral standard which prevailed. In the city of Tai-peh there are 750,000 people, and when I was there 18,321 applications had been received for telephone services. A shipment of 1,200 telephones had just arrived and an advertisement appeared in the press that a public drawing would be conducted in the stadium among the applicants for telephone installations. The authorities would not tolerate any action to which could be attached any sign of suspicion or graft. The public drawing was held and next day the names of the lucky drawers were published in the press. As members of Parliament, we are fairly competent observers, and we should take notice of this sort of thing.

The Government of Formosa had had some trouble with timber, lt is amazing how timber at some time or other always produces government scandals. When that occurred in Formosa, the Government suspended the responsible Minister and practically the whole of the staff of the department which handled timber supplies and a full investigation was begun. While that investigation is proceeding, all timber is being sold by public auction. This is the sort of action that that government takes in order to ensure that the affairs of the island shall be administered on a level that is above suspicion, and as a consequence it has the full confidence of the entire population of Formosa - 10,000,000 persons. The island is about half the size of Tasmania, but every square inch of it is under cultivation. The results have been so good that half its sugar crops and also large quantities of rice have been exported. A magnificent job has been done in primary production there.

Perhaps one of the greatest achievements of the Government of Formosa has been its enactment and implementation of the Land to the Tiller Act, which has overcome the age-old scourge in Asia of rapacious landlords and money lenders. An attempt was made to implement this legislation on the mainland of China when the present regime was in government there, but because men of lesser breed were out to wreck China, it did not succeed. The act has operated in Formosa with amazing success, lt prescribes the size of any area of land in. the island which may be owned. The first step in implementing this act was to divide crown land and to take from the landlords all land exceeding a certain small area. All this land so divided was given to those who were tillers of the soil, and they have the opportunity to purchase their farms within a period of twenty years. For centuries the landlords and money lenders of Asia had mercilessly bled the peasants, but now these farmers have the opportunity not only to work their farms but also to own them.

As we went among the farmers and talked to them I was interested to see how this legislation was working out. I noticed that many farmers had built new brick houses. There was an immense increase in primary production, and in the farmers themselves a new spirit had been generated. I was strongly convinced that this was legislation which could well be copied throughout Asia. I was interested to hear that the Government of Burma had attempted to implement similar legislation but that when it was first introduced trouble was caused on the borders of that country by the Communists.

I was profoundly impressed by the fact that for the first time in Asia, in Formosa the law is above politics. No one can be arrested except on a warrant signed by a public authority, and the officer presenting the warrant must identify himself. That is a procedure completely new to Asia and it sets a pattern which might well be followed throughout all South-East Asian countries.

I conclude by saying that I support the budget and oppose the amendment moved by the Leader of the Opposition (Senator McKenna). I have listened to the moanings about this budget from honorable senators opposite and I am confident that if they continue with their pessimistic complainings, it is certain that Senator McKenna will establish an all-time record in this House as Leader of the Opposition.

talk.start.para: . - In rising to participate in this debate may I say that I oppose the budget and support the amendment moved by thu Leader of the Opposition (Senator McKenna). I expected that the budget would contain proposals for a substantial increase in age and invalid pensions as well as other pension rates, also substantial reductions in sales tax and income tax and other long-overdue concessions. The budget is negative in its approach to the problem of inflation and the ever-increasing prices which are intensifying the inflationary spiral. Apparently, I was misled in my interpretation of a statement made by Senator Spooner during the last sittings of this Senate when he said, in effect, that any disabilities or problems from which the country was then suffering were associated only with prosperity. If that was the position then and the country's economy was really on a stable basis, I was justified in expecting the concessions in the budget which I have mentioned. But instead we got what Paddy shot at - nothing! What is to be done to get the economy back on a stable basis? Not one proposal is made to deal with the problem of inflation, and for that reason the motion of censure against the Government, moved by Senator McKenna by v/ay of an amendment to the motion for the printing of the budget and associated papers, is fully justified. lt is very difficult for the ordinary member of the community to understand the reasoning of this Government when it claims that, during a period of unprecedented prosperity, it is faced with financial and economic difficulties. What the average man understands only too well is that, although to-day he is supposed to be enjoying a standard of living far in advance of that which he previously enjoyed, he is denied the advantages associated with higher wages, because of the rapid increase in the cost of living. The .position is even worse for a man with a large family. In those circumstances, it is very difficult to convince me that we are enjoying a period of unprecedented prosperity, as Senator Spooner would nave us believe. I might say that since the freezing of the basic wage and the suspension of the quarterly cost of living adjustments the workers generally throughout Australia have suffered a very grave injustice because, although wages are pegged, nothing has been done in connexion with prices. Manufacturers and others are more or less-, unbridled in imposing higher prices upon the community, and the "unfortunate consumer is in a position where it is impossible for him to pass on these additional chargesto any one. In the circumstances, one can readily understand why it is difficult for him to swallow the theory advanced by the Minister for National Development (Senator Spooner) that these are only problems associated with prosperity.

speech.para: Obviously, these problems did not developovernight, and it is difficult to understand why this Government did not make some explanation concerning them to the peopleof this country during the general election, in December last. Apparently, when, things are different they are not the same. No explanation was forthcoming. The theme song at that particular time was that Australia was enjoying a period of unprecedented prosperity under the Menzies-Fadden Administration. The Government said to the people, " Return us to power and these conditions will continue ". I am sorry to say that the people took the Government'sword and returned it to power; but 1 submit that if a factual statement and an adequate explanation concerning these problems had been made during the election campaign the results of the election might have been entirely different so far as the set-up in this Parliament is concerned. No one knew that better than did the Government, and for that reason no explanation was forthcoming.

As to inflation, we remember how the Chifley Labour Government faced up to the problem during its term of office by distributing as widely as possible the prosperity which then existed by applying a graduated scale of direct taxation, compelling the wealthier section of the community to pull its full weight in accordance with itsability to pay.. The Chifley Labour Government also stabilized price levels by paying subsidies on the production of essential commodities and, so far as the powers of the Commonwealth permitted it, restricting the prices of those commoditieswhich are more or less part and parcel of our everyday existence. As soon as the Government supported by honora'ble senators opposite took office, it proceeded' forthwith to undo all those things. Subsidies were withdrawn and restrictions were removed from prices and profits. Further, since then, indirect taxation has become the order of the day from the point of view of revenue raising. As a result of this policy, the burden which rightly belongs to the wealthier section of the community has been moved to the shoulders of those on the lower rung of the ladder, the workers in industry, the poorer section of the community, who are least able to carry this burden. Further, because wages are pegged and the quarterly cost of living adjustments suspended, these people are more or less doubly penalized. To make matters worse, the value of the Australian £1 has deteriorated seriously, so much so that it is down 7s. or 8s. on what it was when the present Government took office. And this was the Government that said in 1949 that if it was returned to office it would arrest inflation! This was the Government that promised to keep prices down and to put value back into the £1!

As to indirect taxation, I might say that the Chifley Labour Government realized that sales tax was most unfair in its incidence, and for that reason its policy included progressive reductions year by year, leading ultimately to the complete abolition of this form of. taxation. I remember only too well that the supporters of the present Government, who were then in opposition in the Senate, decried sales tax as an iniquitous and vicious form of taxation. They said further that immediately a Liberal government was returned to power this form of taxation would be completely abolished. Why, the pages of " Hansard " are literally studded with such declarations of policy by supporters of this Government who were then in opposition in the Senate. During the last six years, they have become staunch supporters of higher and higher rates of sales tax.

Sales tax, like many other matters, was intended originally -to be an emergency measure but, under the maladministration of this Government, it has become a permanent source of revenue. Sales tax fails to meet the requirements of equitable taxation based on the principle of ability to pay, because it involves the spending of a proportion of a worker's total wages and a decrease in the proportion saved. In other words, it is much easier for a person on a large income to meet the imposition of sales tax than it is for a worker in industry because the worker has to pay a far greater percentage of his income in living costs, and no account is taken of the purchaser's ecc* nomic position. Notwithstanding this, the Government endeavours to bolster up an indefensible position by claiming that these increases in sales tax and other forms of of indirect taxation are absolutely essential to drain off a portion of the community's spending power for the purpose of offsetting inflation. We know that the wealthier persons and the workers in industry pay the same amount in sales tax on a packet of razor blades or any of the other numerous things which are part and parcel of out everyday existence. It has nothing at all to do with inflation. If this Government is really sincere in its desire to tackle the problem of inflation, it should get down to fundamentals and forget proposals which are of no value other than to create widespread resentment and, to a certain extent, unemployment in certain industries. The Government tells us that heavy taxation is imposed for the purpose of offsetting inflation but, paradoxically, the immediate anil ultimate result is to accelerate the very evil which it is supposed to reduce.
Sitting suspended from 5.45 to 8 p.m.

talk.start.para: - Prior to the suspension of the sitting for dinner, I was dealing with taxation, and pointing out that we have been told by the Government that heavy taxation is imposed for the purpose of curbing inflation. Paradoxically, the immediate and ultimate result is to aggravate the very evil which it is supposed to remedy. Up to date, the Government has not advanced one concrete or positive proposal to stabilize the price level, yet it must be only too obvious to all concerned that, if we are to win the battle against inflation, the first essential is a stable and permanent price level. The Government does not appear to understand the position. Everything that it has done so far has only forced prices higher; figuratively speaking, prices are going up in the elevator, while Wages are climbing up the stairs. In these circumstances, it is very difficult to understand the approach of the Government to the problem of inflation.

speech.para: Both this budget and the supplementary budget have only intensified inflation. To my way of thinking, the supplementary. budget singled out the motor industry for unfair discrimination. The increase of sales tax on motor vehicles certainly placed a most unfair impost on what can no longer be regarded as a luxury industry, because to-day Australia has more commercial motor vehicles per head of the population than any other country. In 1953-54, £790,000,000, or one-fifth of our national income, was spent on motor transport. Indeed, motor transport accounted for 63 per cent, of all passenger-miles, 26 per cent, of all freight-ton miles, and 76 per cent, of all freights carried in Australia. These figures prove conclusively that this industry is absolutely essential to Australia's economy; yet for some reason known only to itself, the Government has singled it out for treatment which, to say the least, is just the reverse of what should be accorded to it. The increase of sales tax on motor cars raised the price of cars from £100 to £200 according to their class. How. this will assist the battle against inflation is certainly beyond my comprehension.

The increase of the petrol tax, for which the supplementary budget provided, has also increased the price of everything consumed in Australia, because of the additional cost of transport. There is no doubt that the policy of this Government in regard to inflation has gone completely hay-wire. The additional yield from this tax is estimated to be approximately £12,000,000 a year, of which £4,000,000 will be used for roads. I should like to know why the whole amount of £12,000,000 could not be used for that purpose. According to the budget, £32,500,000 will be allocated for roads in this financial year, which is £5,500,000 more than was made available for roads last year. I should like to know why the whole of the estimated yield of £50,000,000 from the petrol tax cannot be expended on roads. Why should £17,500,000 of the proceeds of the petrol tax be paid into Consolidated Revenue for general purposes? I believe that this money should be expended on the roads and highways of this country - and many more millions of pounds also!

What we really require in Australia to-day is a national outlook, and a national plan for roads, but that will not materialize while this Government is in power. I always travel by motor car from Adelaide to Canberra in order to attend sittings of the Senate. I have done so for a considerable period of time. My colleague, Senator O'Flaherty, likewise travels to and from Canberra by car. 1 should like to say that I have never seen the roads in a worse condition than they are in at the present time. The well-nigh impossible situation that recently occurred on the Hume Highway makes a farce of the Government's repeated calls for greater efficiency and a lowering of costs in industry, to say nothing of the expenditure of about £200,000,000 a year on defence in Australia. Exactly how much the Holbrook-Tarcutta hold-up actually cost, in terms of immobilized transport, wages and ruined produce, can probably never be assessed, but the amount, if known, would be spectacular. Even then, it must be only the merest fraction of the amount that a hopelessly inadequate, ill-built road system is costing this country every year.

From a defence point of view, the situation that was thrown into relief by the breakdown was more or less ludicrous. Millions and millions of pounds are being expended every year by the Government on defence establishments. We have been told that the purpose of expending £30,000,000 on the St. Mary's ammunitionfilling factory is to enable the services to be armed in the event of war. There is only one thing certain: Should hostilities break out supplies will not be needed where they are produced, but at rendezvous probably hundreds of miles distant from the point of production. In their present state, our road and railway systems would not stand up for one year, or even for one month, given the best of weather conditions, to the demands that would be made upon them in the event of war. 1 know that some responsible authorities are attempting to blame the hauliers - the heavy transport people - for the bad state of the roads to-day, but I cannot agree with that approach to the problem. Surely it is the obligation Qf State governments, working in co-operation with the Commonwealth, to maintain the roads in good repair. The Commonwealth should provide the necessary money out of the defence vote. That is the logical approach to this problem. Surely it is the obligation of the States to ensure that our roads and highways are capable of carrying the most modern transport of the age in order to meet the needs of our people in times of peace, and to assist in the defence of the country in the event of war. 1 leave the matter there. In conclusion, I repeat that I cannot accept the proposals of the Government for a number of reasons. First, they are negative in their approach to the problem of inflation, and with continually rising prices they will further intensify the inflationary spiral. Secondly, the Government's proposal in regard to taxation will result in retarding production at a time when increased production is absolutely essential. My third reason is that the Government's proposals mean that the greatest burden will fall on the backs of the working class- - the people on the lower rungs of the ladder; those engaged in industry who constitute the poorer sections of the community, who are least able to carry the burden. Last, but not least, I oppose them because this Government has failed miserably to keep the promise it made to the people in 1949 - that it would arrest inflation, keep prices down, and put value back into the £1. Those are some of the reasons why I am opposed to the budget and support the amendment moved by the Leader of the Opposition (Senator McKenna).

talk.start.para: .- I rise to support the budget papers which have been placed before the Senate. As the Treasurer (Sir Arthur Fadden) has said, it is a hold-the-line budget, a stand fast budget. Spectacular taxation concessions which would have been so popular with the people are conspicuous by their absence. The budget is marked by sober and restraining influences designed to enable this nation to weather its economic difficulties. No one would allege that those difficulties do not exist, but to suggest, as honorable senators opposite do, that the economy is being dissolved in cataclysmic chaos is sheer nonsense. Their pessimistic utterances remind me of the war correspondent in Evelyn Waugh's " Scoop " who brought about a fisrt-class revolution by reporting incorrectly that one had begun. In the hotel room which I occupied last Wednesday I found a Bible which had been left open by the previous occupant of the room. I noticed that the book was open at the Lamentations of Jeremiah, and as I looked at the page my eyes fell on these writings by the prophet -

quote.para: For these things I weep; mine eye, mine eye runneth down with water . . .

speech.para: I came here to Canberra that evening and listened to the Leader of the Opposition (Senator McKenna) attack the budget. I listened to his catalogue of misery, woe, and lamentation, which was amplified and expanded by other honorable senators opposite. As they spoke, I was waiting for some of them to say, " Mine eye runneth down with water ". In my opinion, that doleful outlook indicates a wrong mental approach to the problems facing us. Let us look at the picture fairly.

The Minister for National Development (Senator Spooner) pointed out that there was a mild boom in the building industry in Australia. He told us that the Government had made- available £30,000,000 to the States for home building. Except for the size of the amount, that is not remarkable. What is remarkable is that the Government has insisted that 20 per cent, of the money allocated to the States shall be made available to co-operative housing societies. Victoria is to receive £10,000,000, which means an additional £2,000,000 for those societies in that State. It is only natural that a Liberal government, which believes in private enterprise, should do all it can to stimulate the growth of co-operative housing societies, because such societies are composed of bands of people who have initiative, courage and enterprise, and are prepared to tackle the problems with which they are confronted. The Government will provide the economic tools and they themselves will get on with the job. These societies provide their own directors, and attend to their own administrative affairs. They function efficiently and more economically than any government housing commission can possibly do. I should like to see the percentages reversed, so that the housing societies would get 80 per cent, of the money to be made available rather than 20 per cent. That is, perhaps, something for which we may look in the not too distant future.

I believe that increased housing accommodation is vital to our national well-being. Unless adequate accommodation is made available, parents cannot give their children the proper home life and upbringing which is necessary for their spiritual and material welfare. If we want to know how strong a nation is, we have only to look at its homes. We can learn a lesson in this field by going back to early Greek history. Why is it that Rome fell? I know that we have to provide the States with money for gaols, mental asylums, houses of correction, police forces, and so on; but we could save millions of pounds in those directions if we were prepared to spend thousands of pounds on prevention. If the home life of the community reached the level that it should reach, we could almost forget about juvenile delinquency. As a lawyer practising in Victoria, 1 know that four out of every five juvenile delinquents come from broken homes, or no homes at all. The Government should take every step within its fiscal power to encourage the people to set up their own private castles.

I should like to see sales tax removed from every article directly or indirectly connected with homes. I know that building materials are largely free from sales tax, but fixtures, fittings and many laboursaving devices used in homes are not free. If any honorable senator thinks that a washing machine, or a refrigerator, is a luxury I suggest that he should tell that to the mother of four or five children. If he does so, he will find that her reaction to his suggestion will not be good. In my opinion, sales tax at any time is an unfair tax, because it is not based on ability to pay, and is not graduated according to income. It strikes the poverty-stricken family man as harshly as it does the wealthy bachelor. I hope the time will come when we shall be able to congratulate the Treasurer on the total abolition of sales tax. That cannot be now, but any relaxation would be welcome.

Several honorable senators opposite have made passing references to our economic situation. They have predicted that we shall be ruined before the end of the year unless effective control of prices is reintroduced. I do not impugn their sincerity when they trot out this economic panacea, but it is somewhat odd that they should advocate control of prices now, when in 1939, at a time when the enemy was almost at our gates, and prices control was introduced, every member of the Labour party voted against it. What has happened since then? No one can accuse the Labour party of having made any progress in economic thinking. Those who think that the party has made any progress should ask Professor Arndt what he thinks about it. If prices control is to be effective it must be accompanied by wage pegging, rationing and a plethora of other controls as essential concomitants. I do not know what it is that makes honorable senators opposite believe that we can bring about the millennium by reverting in peace-time to the economic barbarism of prices control, wages control and rationing. Do not say that we can have the first two controls without the third, because we cannot. If honorable senators believe that we can, they should read the late Mr. Chifley's speeches on rationing and subsidies which were delivered at the time the prices referendum was rejected by the people. Imagine a voluntary reversion to a method which simply registered increased costs and made them legal - to an era of planned shortages, blackmarkets, racketeers and frustrating controls. Prices control failed the ancient Romans, and it would fail us.

I believe that Professor John Jewkes in his book, " Ordeal by Planning " has dealt the coup de grace to this style of economic thought. In that book Professor Jewkes speaks of England under a socialist regime in 1947, but the same principles apply to this country. This gentleman was a planner for the British Government during World War II., and he continued his activities under the socialists. More in sorrow than in anger, and in a series of masterly understatements, he has destroyed the fortress of the socialists, the central economic planners, plank by plank and shibboleth by shibboleth. Dealing with some of the absurdities of the central economic planners involved in prices control and rationing, at page 217 of his book he gives these examples -

quote.para: A market gardener requires a new shaft for a wheelbarrow, a piece of wood costing perhaps ninepence. A licence must be applied for from the surveyor of the district council on the appropriate form. The licence has to be registered and filed by the district* surveyor and then presented to, registered and filed by the timber merchant. A local authority for roads wishes to improve visibility at a dangerous junction by substituting some twenty yards of iron fence for the existing hedge. To obtain permission to do this five enormous forms and nine maps, some of them coloured, have to be prepared and submitted. The despatch of a small shipment of six drums of lubricating oil involves the filling in of forty-six forms, requiring forty-two signatures, not including the customer's invoice or delivery notes. A local authority cannot increase the pocket-money of a child under its care without first obtaining sanction from the Home Office. Newspapers are fined for exceeding more than 55 per cent, of advertising matter. A firm is fined for making 60,000 frying-pans for the home market, although it is established by evidence that the firm had done this only because of long delays by the Board of Trade in providing an export licence, a licence which in fact had been received after the fine had been imposed. Four Lincolnshire farmers are fined £1,200 for growing canary seed. Mrs. Shenton, aged 79, is fined £10 for growing too few potatoes; she said she had responded to a Ministry broadcast appeal to grow more wheat.
Producers struggle to work through a coil of regulations that must defeat all but' the hardiest or the most unscrupulous.

speech.para: That is the type of economic jungle to which the Labour party would have us step backwards. It is, of course, pointless simply to say that our opponents' principles are wrong. It behoves us to say what we should do in a positive fashion to correct the position. I turn now to the free economy remedy. This is what I believe to be a key feature in a free economy, the necessary machinery to preserve a free economy in the world of to-day. Like all supporters of this Government I believe in the virtue of free enterprise, but one of our difficulties at the moment is that while the industrial economy is largely private, it is in many cases not enterprising. The reason for that is the absence of real competition due to monopolies and restrictive trade practices.

In order to overcome this position and to make a positive attack on the inflationary spiral by restoring reality to competition in commerce, I urge the Government to introduce legislation along the lines of the Sherman anti-trust, anti-monopoly legislation of the United States of America. It is of course natural that a government which believes in private ownership of the means of production should do all things necessary to curb monopolies. It was a Liberal government which introduced the Australian Industries Preservation Act of 1911, which does something, but is hopelessly inadequate in 1956. It might be argued that the constitutional powers of the Commonwealth would not support legislation of this type, but I believe that view to be wrong because the very first placitum of Section 51 of the Constitution gives this power to the Commonwealth. At all events it is much more likely that the Commonwealth has power to introduce legislation of (his type than it had to nationalize the banks. There is little doubt that if a referendum for the purpose is necessary, it would be successful if supported by the major political parties. I suggest that in a matter of this kind the support of all parties would be forthcoming in an attempt to solve the nation's economic difficulties. This power might even be referred by the States. The progressive Bolte Government in Victoria is already preparing State legislation to curb certain restrictive trade practices, and perhaps other States will fall into line.

May I now say something of the type of legislation that was introduced into the United States in 1890. This type of antimonopoly legislation was first introduced in 1890 to deal with certain activities of the Rockefeller empire, and was amended by Clayton in 1914 and Robinson in 1936 to improve its procedure. The act is administered by a federal trade commission, and is aimed at horizontal and vertical monopolies, trade cartels and unfair or restrictive trade practices. Another important but less dominating section, deals with the control of advertising and attempts to put truth in advertising. The act is admittedly clumsy in operation, but it has a wonderful deterrent effect on the would-be commercial buccaneer in the United States. For every one person convicted under the act a thousand must be deterred. Du Pont Industries, Standard Oil, Stetson Hats, Kodak and Judson Rivets are some of the well-known names which have been effectively dealt with in the United States.

Under the legislation a manufacturer is not allowed to own an enterprise in the field in which his product is used. For example, an aircraft manufacturer cannot own an airline, and a company producing film is not allowed to own a chain of theatres. All action is taken to make competition a reality. I do not attribute the sole success of the American economy to this legislation, but we must remember that from 1945 until about 1952 the free enterprise economy of the United States carried the free world on its back. In Australia one of our difficulties arises from the fact that a number of manufacturers who make particular goods, instead of competing for markets, get together and zone the market out. Instead of the keen prices that we might reasonably expect from competition we get an inflated price due to the absence of competition. The manufacturer is secure in the knowledge that the other manufacturers or members of (he cartel will not undercut him. If we make competition a reality, 1 believe that while we shall not completely solve our economic difficulties, we shall at least be on the right track, lt is infinitely better for the economy to have a large number of small independent businesses rather than the one monopoly, whether it be a private or a State monopoly.

Perhaps I might give an example which explains my point better than a reference to the sections. There was a derelict salmon-canning company which had a poor quality salmon that was just off-white or a little pink. As a result, it was difficult to make sales. The company began to advertise that its salmon did not turn pink in the tins. Housewives in America, who read the advertisements, began to believe that all the good pink salmon that was canned by other manufacturers was tainted, or would make them candidates for ptomaine poisoning. There was a rush on the inferior article. The Federal Trade Commissioner stepped in and, by appropriate action, restrained the lying advertiser from pursuing that course of conduct, and restored the trade in canned salmon to its proper perspective.

A large proportion of the revenue raised by the Commonwealth is lent to the States for public works. The Commonwealth collects the taxes and the odium. On the other hand, the States cannot act as truly sovereign bodies if they are not responsible for raising their own revenue. Victoria, under a progressive government, has bolted to the forefront of industrial development. It does not object to the Commonwealth Government assisting the smaller States, but it does believe that the present uniform taxation formula discriminates unfairly against Victoria. The sooner uniform taxation goes, whether by court decision or by legislative action, the better.
It would still be open to the financially weak States to receive special grants as provided by the Constitution.

This budget supports a sensible foreign policy. Australia has never stood higher in the councils of the nations than it does under the present Government. Australia has been singularly honoured in the choice of its Prime Minister (Mr. Menzies) to handle the delicate negotiations with the Egyptians over the Suez Canal. From press reports, the negotiations have been conducted ably and without threats. At all events, although there has been no immediate success on a delegation level, the discussions were amicable and friendly.. Perhaps' I might quote from the Labour party's favourite prophet, Jeremiah, who in Chapter 5, verse 6, declared -

quote.para: We have given the hand to the Egyptians. . . to be satisfied with bread.

speech.para: We are no longer rude and insulting to our friends or obsequious to our enemies. The Moscow crawl is a dance that went out of fashion in Australia in 1949 and, despite many attempts to introduce it, we have banned the Peking shuffle. Australia has not forgotten how the Minister for External Affairs in the previous Labour Government evicted the Americans from Manus Island. How much more soundly could we sleep in our beds if we knew that this great ally had a major defence base athwart the route from Asia. The eviction of the Americans was the type of political lunacy for which the perpetrator would have been impeached in earlier and more robust days.

This Government will not allow Communistcontrolled trade unions or any one else to dictate its foreign policy. The way in which Comrade Healy was able to impose his will on the Labour Government in connexion with Dutch shipping at the close of World War II. was an alarming lesson. 1 remind honorable senators of the case of the Dutch cruiser " Piet Hien ". This vessel was supporting the landings of Australian troops in the Indies at the end of the war. When hostilities ceased, the ship needed repairs and limped south to Fremantle. Its commander thought he was going to a friendly port, but the Communistcontrolled unions decided that Dutch vessels were black. The gallant ship went to Melbourne as it was not believed that any government worthy of the name would tamely surrender to such blackmail. The reception in Melbourne was disappointing, and the ship went on to Sydney. The black ban held there also, and because the Minister for External Affairs of the day had a gelatinous compound where spinal vertebrae should have been, our ally's ship was forced by a Communist ban to go to New Zealand. That sort of conduct in our foreign relations will never be repeated while this Government is in office.
For the reasons I have given, I support the budget. According to the press, there have been broad hints of a challenge to the

Government on the budget by honorable senators opposite. Senator Hendrickson challenged the Government to resign and fight. At the risk of wearying him, and other honorable senators on the Opposition side, I refer them again to their prophet, Jeremiah, who made a comment which is remarkably relevant to the treatment given by the electors to the Australian Labour party candidates at the last general election. These are the words of Jeremiah, at chapter 5, verse 22 of the Lamentations -

quote.para: But thou hast utterly rejected us; thou art very wroth against us.

talk.start.para: . - I wish to offer my congratulations to Senator Hannan, who has just resumed his seat, on the eloquence and sincerity with which he delivered his maiden speech to the Senate. While, naturally, I disagree with many of the political arguments he advanced, I believe it might be said with confidence that he has shown that he will be a valuable unit in this chamber to assist the party which he is privileged to represent. Before proceeding to consideration of the budget, I might be pardoned some brief reference to the general election for the Commonwealth Parliament which took place on 10th December last. On that occasion, the Anti-Communist Labour party, of which I am a member, received the votes of 300,000 electors of Australia. Although it contested seats in only four States, it was unable to put forward its maximum effort because of the short notice of the campaign.

speech.para: I wish to thank all those who gave their support to our party, and to say to them that I hope that support will continue, because we have embarked upon a struggle which we know will be a long one. We know also that, in that struggle, staying power will count, and I assure those who supported us and others that we will see that struggle through to the finish. In Victoria, where our party has the support of more than 200 of the Australian Labour party branches, we polled one-sixth of the total vote and received the support of one-third of the Labour votes. As 33 members of the House of Representatives and five senators were elected, and we obtained one-sixth of the votes, we might have expected to obtain one-sixth of the number of members elected for Victoria, that is, six or seven. Owing to the nature of the electoral system, however, we had one elected, and I have heard rumours that the election of that one candidate has not been received with joy in some quarters.

A publication of the Evatt Labour party known as " Tocsin " - a name with a not altogether pleasing sound, and I hasten to add. that it is spelt " Tocsin " and not " Toxin " - suggested that the election of one senator for Victoria from the AntiCommunist Labour party was' an accident because we drew No. 1 place on the ballot-paper. I can only say that I have referred the votes cast in the election to two eminent authorities on statistical method. Both of them say that it was not an accident and that, on the votes, we would have elected a senator even if we had not obtained the first position on the ballot-paper. Nevertheless, it continued to be said, and has been said even in this chamber, that the election of one senator representing our party was an accident. I was unable to understand the reason for that, until on reference to my dictionary I discovered that the definition of " accident " is a " happening as a result of which somebody feels hurt ". 1 propose now to deal with the budget. I am in entire agreement with my leader - our party is unanimous - in believing that the budget is unimaginative because it contains no overall plan to safeguard the economic future of Australia. It is depressing because the burdens in it fall too heavily on the underprivileged and lower income groups. It is ineffective because strong measures have not been taken to protect our economy against the undesirable activities of vested interests. Those are general charges; but specifically, as a matter of principle, we cannot and will not accept that portion of the budget which provides that a big part of the burden of salving the economy of this country shall be placed upon the pensioners and widows. Our stand upon that is a matter of principle. It has been represented in some quarters as a threat, but I deny that it is a threat. I have not been long in this place but it would surprise me if it can be interpreted as a threat when any party, on the basis of principle, declares that it is not prepared to accept a particular provision in a particular measure.

Dealing with the budget, I say at the outset that any measure of importance which comes before this House has to be looked at from two main points of view. The first is that of external security, and the second that of internal prosperity. The two subjects I should like to deal with first are those which affect our external security - defence and immigration. In my opinion, the events of the last five years have, shown that in this country the one problem that transcends all others is that of our external security. We have been used to imagine in this country that we live in a kind of international vacuum, and many of us appear to assume that in ten or fifteen years' time the system of government in this country will be the same as it is to-day. That is an assumption which, in view of the character of world affairs, no man is entitled to make. When, five years ago, 500,000,000 Chinese people came under Communist rule nothing could ever be the same again for the people of this country. Therefore, in spite of the suggestions of the starry-eyed peace-lovers who assembled in Sydney last week-end under the impression that they were working for peace, when actually they were being manipulated by the Communist party in order to reach decisions which were purely propaganda for the foreign policy of the Soviet Union, the party which I represent will continue to say that the greatest issue that we must consider in this Parliament and in Australia to-day is that of external security. I am glad, therefore, that the Government resisted pressure from influential quarters to reduce the defence vote. It is true that the vote is substantially the same as last year, and under rising costs that means to some extent a cut, but I say that these are not times in which risks can be taken on defence. I am pleased, therefore, that the Government has determined to give defence a high priority in its expenditure.

I am pleased also with suggestions that the air will receive some preference, because the late John Curtin was the first man in this Parliament to advocate that stress should be laid upon our air defences. I regret that at the same time as we are told that it is necessary, in view of international difficulties, to keep our defences at a high state of efficiency, we should hear talk of dismissals and the dispersal of staff from our aircraft factories and naval dockyards. Personnel engaged in these factories and dockyards, in some cases, due to the exceptional nature of the tolerances they must observe in the processes of manufacture, take twelve months to train. So, it fills me with alarm to think that in the near future the skilled staff in some of these establishments may be dispersed. I hope that suggestions which have appeared in the press that the Government is exploring the possibility of retaining this staff by allowing these establishments to contract for outside work will bear fruit.

The second matter to which I turn is immigration. I regret the cut that has been made by the Government in immigration, although I realize that tremendous pressure has been put upon it, both from sections that support it as well as from sections that oppose it. I regret that the cut was made in association with a statement that implied a slur upon a section of the immigrants. The statement was that cuts would be made in regard to southern European immigrants. That was entirely unnecessary. I do not know who was to blame. I do not think it would be the Immigration Department, because under Mr. Calwell, when he was Minister for Immigration, and under the present Minister, it has been meticulously careful to see that nothing is done to give offence to the national susceptibilities of any people. I regret that that should have been said because there is a smack in it of the doctrine of Nordic superiority against which we were supposed to have fought in the recent war.

We have been told that to some extent the cuts will be for the welfare of the immigrants, that some of them are living under overcrowded conditions - as though our own fathers when they came to this country left the boat and moved into luxuriously furnished flats. It is true that if we are to bring immigrants here the conditions under which they will have to live at times will not be all that we would desire; but what we have to realize is that we are fighting against time to populate this country. We have to realize that we are told by our military advisers that we should be in a position to defend ourselves within, not 50, but ten years. In those circumstances we should be prepared, if necessary, to take risks in order to populate our country. I refer the Senate in its consideration of what attitude we should adopt upon immigration to a statement which was made at the immigration convention held early this year. It is a statement by Mr. Albert Monk, of the Australian Council of Trades Unions, a statement which I consider to be so adequate to the point that I propose to read it. Mr. Monk said - lt takes years of good administration and public relations work to build up the goodwill upon which really successful immigration rests. If we are to 'attract the best migrants, in these days of -European prosperity, we must be able to show them and their governments that Australia is con- sistently sincere in its desire to receive them as permanent settlers and that there are, and will continue to be opportunities for them to improve their position by adopting this country as a new homeland. If however at the first chilly blast of a temporary unfavourable economic situation we make drastic reductions in the immigration programme, the usually garbled and exaggerated impressions created by embellished press stories abroad appear to be confirmed, and the confidence built up by painstaking years of work can be shattered overnight.
In speaking against any tinkering with migration, Mr. Monk concluded by saying that we have to remember this lesson -

quote.para: The flow of migrants cannot be turned on and -off like a tap.

speech.para: Turning now to the essentials of the budget, it has been criticized by our party as unimaginative. I support that view because, to my way of thinking, the principles upon which it is based appear to be the principles of orthodoxy carried to excess. I am one of those who suffered to some extent, but not as much as others, in the last depression. Since that date, I have listened to speakers of all schools of political thought suggesting that we learned a great deal from that depression, and that there will not be any further depressions because we have learned how to deal with them. I have had plans outlined to me by speakers of both the conservative and the radical type, pointing out that when a recession occurs - which is supposed to be the half-way house to depression - it can be dealt with by wise governmental measures. Credit is not tightened unnecessarily. The Government uses money for public works and endeavours to foster employment, and so on.

I regret to say that I find in this budget none of those expedients which we were supposed to have learned from the last depression. On the contrary, it appears to me that to a large extent it is based upon the same principles that preceded the budgets of the pre-1930 period. What is happening in this community to-day, as a result? There is the same tightening of credit as was evident in 1929, except in the case of the hire-purchase companies, which seem to be able to get plenty of money because they are reaping 18 per cent, profit from thentransactions. But there is the same cry for economies - as though any government was not called upon to carry out economies at all times, and not merely in periods of recession. The same uneasy feeling is developing in the community that was evident in former years, that the form that the economies might take will be the dismissal of the lower-paid employees.

I regret that no attempt has been made in the budget to branch out and investigate or try out new ideas. The directions in which I should have liked to see the Government experiment with new ideas are particularly those in regard to indirect taxation. If we consider the pay-roll tax and the sales tax, we find that although these are two sources from which the Government reaps large sums in taxation, by their nature and because of the method by which they are applied, they conduce to and promote inflation. When the manufacturer manufactures his goods, he adds the payroll tax to his costs and then determines his percentage of profit. He sells the article to the middleman, who does the same thing. Although the pay-roll tax is there all the time, because of it the amount of profit is increased; consequently, the retail price is increased and inflation is promoted. Within recent weeks, an eminent accountant suggested to me. that in the case of payroll tax, in particular, just as much is added to profit because of the tax as it yields to the Treasury. It would be an excellent thing if the Government could investigate the possibility of reefing off an amount equal to the pay-roll tax yield at some point in a particular transaction. If that cannot be done, 1 suggest that the eminent economists who are advising the Government might be called upon to examine the situation to find whether, after all, it would not be possible to utilize some other system of taxation which would not, by its very nature, conduce to inflation.

I regret that the Government has done nothing with regard to capital issues, and bonus shares in particular. We have heard a great deal of eloquence in regard to the quarterly adjustment of wages, and we have repeatedly read in the" press reports of the issue of bonus shares to lucky shareholders. I suggest that, although there may be constitutional or other difficulties in the way of dealing with capital issues, some investigation might be made into measures which are being taken by other governments with a view to discouraging at least these issues of bonus shares. In Canada, for example, in the case of new issues of such capital, the firms concerned are informed that they will receive no allowance for depreciation for some years to come.

I come now to the matter which we, as a party, regard as fundamental - the question of the pensioners. I suppose that, within the last few days, every honorable senator has received from pensioners, and from people who have intense sympathy with pensioners, letters asking that we should do all that we can to obtain some reconsideration of the Government's decision in regard to pensions. I feel that honorable senators on both sides of the House will have read those letters with sympathy and with concern, and I hope that even at this late stage it may be possible for the Government to give fresh consideration to this particular matter upon which all sections of the community feel deeply. The Government's decision has received the unanimous, condemnation of the press of this country, but it could still be re-examined and brought before this Parliament in a form that would merit the approbation of all parties. f do not wish to be unpleasant, but is it not a fact that in the mind of the pensioner to-day is the fact that a decision was made by parliamentarians, all of whom recently received a. large increase of salary, and by public servants, all of whom received large increases of salary, that the economic salvation of this country could be brought about by not increasing the admittedly small pension now received by the pensioner? No one in this House would suggest for a moment that he could live on £4 a week, and in the- circumstances I suggest that the

Government should look at the matter again and treat it, not upon the basis of figures in books pf account, but upon the basis of human values. If nothing can be done in regard to the matter at least we owe this to the pensioner, that we should erect in this capital a national shrine inscribed, " To the unknown pensioner ", in memory of those thousands of pensioners who, if this is persisted with, will lay down their lives for the economic salvation of their country.

In regard to child endowment, our party supports the policy of the Australian Council of Trades Unions which has already been set out by 0Jr leader, Senator Cole. I know that it will be suggested that if we are going to do all these things, if we are going to give money to the pensioners, if we are going to increase child endowment, extra taxation will be required. I know also that in another place a challenge was issued to anybody who was prepared to support extra taxation for these purposes; and I want to say now that if the only way in which we can give justice to the pensioner and to the family man is by increasing taxation, then let us do it. I believe, however, that we ought to utilize some of the £109,000,000 or £110,000,000 surplus which we are told will be available, or which we hope will be available at the conclusion of the financial year. We have also been told that a large proportion of that money will be required in case loans which come up for redemption next year are not adequately redeemed. I suppose one of the reasons why there may be difficulty in redeeming the loans next year is the fact that hire-purchase companies are able to offer more attractive terms to investors and, in those circumstances, investors are inclined to place their money with hire-purchase companies instead of in loans. I suggest, therefore, that the proper measure to adopt would be one calculated to do something about hire purchase, and I suggest also that something be done about that matter when the State Premiers and representatives of the Commonwealth Government next meet in conference.

Let me say in conclusion that I listened with considerable interest, and with some sympathy to the final plea made by the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator O'sullivan) in the course of his remarks last week when he suggested that it was desirable in the interests of this country that there be co-operation between the Government and the trade unions. That is desirable at all times, but if such cooperation is to exist it is necessary, first of all, that something be done to dispel the feeling of trade unionists that their wages are being attacked and that they are to be among the principal victims who are to be forced to salve the economy of the country. Again, if there is to be co-operation, it is necessary that the trade unions be in good hands. At another time, I hope to have something to say on that final point. I close my remarks by repeating that there are many features of this budget with which I and my colleague, Senator Cole, do not agree, and that have have made up our minds on one point of principle, lt is that we cannot and will not support that section of the budget which suggests that the pensioners of this country, both age and widows, shall bear a major part in salving the economic destinies of Australia.

talk.start.para: . - As a new member of the Senate, I have listened with a great deal of interest to this, the debate on the 1956 budget. At the outset, 1 should like to congratulate the two preceding speakers, Senator Hannan and Senator McManus, upon their very fine contributions. I frankly admit that they have set a standard which 1 find it most difficult to emulate. It is true that speakers on both sides of the chamber, in the course of their utterances, have propounded a policy of defence and development of Australia. It is also true that without exception they have admitted that the greatest single factor mitigating against our development to-day is inflation; but there is the widest possible divergence in their opinions as to what steps should be- taken to remedy the position. Unlike so many of my colleagues, 1 am not competent to analyse the cause and effects of inflation. I shall, therefore, confine my remarks to basic principles which, although they may be called elementary, are nevertheless fundamental. It is on that basis that I propose to make my short contribution, and what I have to say will hinge upon consolidating what we have with a developmental policy that will rid us of this monster.

speech.para: Australia is a young country. In the last two decades we have' passed through most difficult times. During the war years, we suffered shortages and restrictions and shouldered all sorts of responsibilities cheerfully because ours was an all-in effort. During the last decade we have had some difficulty in readjusting our mode of life. It is true that we have had most bountiful seasons and high prices for our primary products during the last ten years, and this, together with other factors, has created an inflationary tendency. I suggest that to go on expanding in inflationary circumstances with costs spiralling must ultimately defeat our efforts to expand. In those circumstances, we have no alternative but to give some consideration to consolidation, and that is where this budget has a most steadying effect upon our economy. The first reactions of any individual to any budget are partisan, or personal. If. we read in our local press that our rates have gone up 1 s., our first comment is, " What for? 1 have not seen a council vehicle in my street for the last ten years ". If we read in our morning press that the State budget has been presented, the first thing we do is to scan through the contents in order to see how it is going to affect us personally, how it will affect our way of life, our businesses, OU wages or our profits. That is only natural. If that is true of municipal and State budgets, it is no under-statement to say it is true of federal budgets because the Commonwealth Government is charged with the responsibility of defending and developing Australia. I, therefore, suggest that for the time being we forget our personal reactions and have a quick look at the effect that this budget will have upon the economy of Australia.

Australia is basically a primary-producing country. We rely upon our primary products for our overseas markets. We should, therefore, consider how some of those primary industries can affect our future. It is true that the wool industry is enjoying a marked measure of prosperity lo-day; but there is no room for complacency on thai score because ever-increasing costs can have a detrimental effect upon the economy of the producer. ! invite honorable senators to give some thought to the tremendous effort being made by overseas interests to develop synthetics to compete with wool. It would be a sad day for this country if we found that our market had disappeared overnight because we as a people did nol realize that we had to be up ,and doing. For thai reason, the time has come when a great dead more -talent and finance must be made available fox the technical expansion of the wool industry..

Oar second largest primary industry, wheat, as not 'in such a happy position. Unlike wool, wheat has to meet fierce competition on overseas -markets. Huge surpluses have been built -up, and to-day we find it increasingly difficult to sell our products, with unfortunate results on our overseas balances. To-day, it costs 7s. 6d. to send a bushel of wheat from Australia to the United Kingdom. The first time that I got 5s. a bushel for growing wheat, I thought that I was a millionaire. But there are factors outside the control of the Government that are having a most adverse effect on the wheat industry to-day. The eastern States, as never before, have suffered from flood and deluge and saturation to such a point that many growers are today faced with a most unhappy prospect. It is not uncommon, in the affected three States, to hear farmers say, " I have prepared 1,000 acres of fallow, but I have not sown the seed, and it is now too late to do so ". That is a rather melancholy picture, when we realize that, ordinarily, they make a valuable contribution to our overseas balance, lt is also a melancholy picture for the poor individual who has expended his money and time in good husbandry, and does not get the chance of a return because he cannot even sow his crop.

I suggest to you, Mr. President, in all seriousness, that a great need of the wheat grower and, to some extent, of the driedfruit grower to-day is a relaxation of credit restrictions. I want to make it perfectly clear that it is not Government policy to put a blanket on credit for the developmental and seasonal advances required by primary industry. Therefore, it cannot be laid at the door of the Government that it has put a blanket on all credit, and is thus responsible for the position that has arisen. It is true that to-day there is more money in this country than we have ever seen, but, unfortunately, it is not being channelled into the right directions. The grower who goes to a financial institution for an advance is invariably told by the manager: " I am awfully sorry. I should like to help you, but we have no money available for that purpose ". Yet considerable amounts of money are being channelled into hire purchase companies, which are paying fantastic # rates of interest. The point that I want to make is this: As a people, we must put first things first. A product that makes possible our overseas payments should take priority over other things that have no Teal value on that score. Therefore, I say to the Government, which has declared that it expects normal seasonal advances to "be made, that it should watch this position very closely, because it could deteriorate rapidly and the effects could be disastrous.

I want to congratulate the Government on the splendid relief that it gave to the dried fruit-growers in Victoria. They, too, have suffered hardship through wet seasons. The Government made available to them £300,000 - a very considerable amount - and I want to say that the growers are very grateful.

I desire now to make a brief comment about the tobacco industry, which can be developed and expanded tremendously. Both the growers and the manufacturers have stated that Australia can produce leaf equivalent to any in the world. To-day, this country is expending 40,000,000 dollars a year on the importation of tobacco leaf. There is no need for me to remind the Senate that that is a considerable sum of money, and the Government will, I feel sure, do all that it possibly can to develop this industry, for the very good reason that it is vital to Australia as a dollar saver. But we cannot consolidate our industries unless we have an efficient transport system - life lines that are effective.

I should like to direct attention to a matter which, in my opinion, demands the closest and most urgent co-operation between the States and the Commonwealth. I refer to the interstate highways. It is true that the propounders of the Constitution could never have foreseen the day that heavy road transports would pound our interstate highways to pieces. Therefore, they cannot be charged with negligence when they framed the Constitution. But what do we see to-day? We have the farcical position of State Parliaments passing legislation to try to make the interstate road haulier pay just charges, and the hauliers, in turn, challenging the legislation in the highest court in the land, where it has been negatived. The interstate road hauliers are snapping their fingers at State legislation, and they will continue to pound our roads until there is nothing left to pound. But I am speaking, not in the interest of the hauliers, but in the interests of the development and defence of this country. Unless we can evolve a Commonwealth plan to make these people pay their just contribution, and produce a road plan that will be permanent and effective we, as a government, are running a very grave risk of being charged with not doing our national duty. Therefore, I suggest, with great respect, that the Government take the initiative in calling together the representatives of the States on this very important matter. They should even be kept in Canberra at government expense until a worth-while and workable plan is produced. Before I leave the subject of roads, I want to make one more suggestion. I know from experience the difficulties that confront the country municipalities in this connexion. From one year to another, the country municipalities do not know what will be the amount of government grants for roads. I am not criticizing the Government in this matter, because even its most caustic critics must admit that it has made increasingly greater grants for road works and maintenance. The amount now made available annually by the Commonwealth^ for this purpose is an all-time record. There is no quarrel on that account. But because grants are made only yearly, the municipalities are in the unhappy position of themselves having to decide whether to expend, say, from £7,000 to £8,000 on a grader to carry out certain work this yea:-, when they might have to shed it next year if the work cannot be continued. This is an aspect of the matter that should be considered. I know that it bristles with difficulties. There must be estimates, and some guesswork, but I am not convinced that we cannot produce a means of giving the municipalities stability.

I have time now to make only a very brief reference to secondary industry. I know that what I have to say will not be popular; it could even be dynamite. Still and all, let us have a look at it. We have made tremendous strides with our secondary industries in the last few years, and I deplore the fact that certain people are inclined to decry their value in the economy. Critics say, " As we can never become an exporter of secondary products, why persevere with them? " But, if we stop for a moment to reflect on the situation, we must frankly admit that secondary products are playing an ever-increasing role in our economy. Secondary industriesare employing increasing numbers of workers. In a world of tight economies, it is necessary for us to expand all our industries. But what is the position to-day? From the point of view of secondary industry, Australia is trying to compete on world markets against the products of countries whose standards of living have little or no relation to the methods of production. We have priced ourselves out of markets, even those that are close to us. Our first objective must be to maintain the standard of living that is inherently British and our own. What is the solution? I shall give it in a few words: From management to office boy we must all make a greater effort. The Australian workman has proved that he can produce goods in quantities and of quality second to none in the world, and, therefore, I suggest that the only solution which will enable us to maintain our standard of living is that we, as a people, shall accept the challenge of other nations, and say that we will produce a little more, work a little harder, and so retain for ourselves those markets that rightfully should be ours.

I do not wish to cast a silent vote on the vexed question of pensions. Critics of the Government are most caustic in their remarks concerning taxation, which they claim has reached astronomical proportions. They cry aloud for a reduction of taxes. At the same time, they accuse the Government of being niggardly and parsimonious in its attitude towards social services. They cannot have it both ways; they must make up their minds what they want. If they want more to be paid by way of pensions, and are prepared to pay the taxes which would make that possible, let them say so. Some play is made on the fact that the Government is budgeting for a surplus of £108,000,000; but have those people who criticize the Government for making that provision forgotten that during this financial year the Government is obliged to take up loans that were raised to enable Australia to make its war effort? Have they forgotten that we must be prepared to meet the urgent and unprecedented needs of the States faced with disaster? Where else can the States go for help other than to the Commonwealth, where they have always gone? They have never been refused help in time of need. Having said that, I add that I do not think that any member of this chamber would do other than try to make the lot of the aged people and invalids in our country a little easier. From my own observations, I can say truthfully that certain sections of those in receipt of pensions have greater needs than others have. I refer to the aged and infirm, and those who are incapable of earning anything to add to their income, and are unable to look after themselves. I should like the Government to give special consideration to their needs, and I have every reason to believe that action along those lines will be taken at the first opportunity.

Before I conclude, I wish to refer to the disastrous floods which have occurred in Victoria during recent weeks, but I have no desire to traverse the ground so eloquently covered by other speakers on both sides of the chamber. I wish, however, to mention one place in Victoria, which is typical of many other places, At Redcliffs, which is situated on a bend of the river Murray, there is one of the most modern pumping and generating plants in the southern hemisphere. It is worth £1,500,000. As honorable senators know, heavy rain caused old man Murray to come down as he had not done for years, with the result that the pumping plant was threatened. A cry went out for help. What was the result? Labourers downed their tools, traders shut the doors of their shops, professional men left their offices, and went as one man to do a job, counting not the cost to themselves. They worked with almost fanatical zeal, and they have left their monument in levee banks that will be seen for years to come. Mention of men who worked as fanatics reminds me that no less a person than Sir Winston Churchill once described a fanatic as a man who cannot change his mind and will not change the subject. If this Parliament can help to instil into the people of this country some of the spirit shown by the men to whom I have referred, then the future of this nation is assured. I do not believe that a depression is just around the corner to overwhelm us, but I do believe that no government, acting on its own, can destroy the monster of inflation. Governments may guide and counsel, but in the long run the solution is in the hands of the people, who must make a supreme effort, as they have always done in Australia in times of crisis. If we face our responsibilities in the right spirit, the future of this great land is assured.

talk.start.para: .- At the outset of my remarks I compliment the three preceding speakers who have delivered their maiden speeches here to-night. At some time or other, each of us has gone through a similar ordeal. The speeches to which we have listened this evening have been most interesting.

speech.para: I desire to refer to some statements made during this debate by the Minister for the Navy (Senator O'sullivan) and by Senator Wright. I am amazed that the former honorable senator, who is the Leader of the Government in this chamber, should have referred as he did to certain restrictions that were in force in 1949, and prior to that year. It is true that, during the period referred to, certain restrictions were in operation, but as honorable senators know, Australia had then just emerged from a war in which the whole strength of the nation had been mobilized. There was a lot of money in the hands of the men and women who were being discharged from the fighting services, and, because of the concentration on the war effort, there were few goods available. One might expect statements of the kind made by the Minister from people without experience, but it ill-became the Leader of the Government in this chamber to speak as he did, because surely he knew the reason for the restrictions that were in force. The second point that he made would have been amusing had it not been so tragic. He referred to the amount of money spent on defence in 1949 by the Chifley Government, and contrasted it with the amount that will be spent by the Government under the budget that has just been presented to the Parliament. He qualified his contentions with remarks such as " Never in the history of Australia in peacetime has our country been in a better defence position ". Well, all that I need say in answer to that is contained in reported statements by Sir Frederick Shedden published in the " Sydney Morning Herald ", which is a journal that supports the present Administration. That newspaper reported that Sir Frederick Shedden had said -

quote.para: Australia is not ready for mobilization . . . the services have not been able to achieve the permanent forces targets provided in the estimates . . . the Government has not made any decision upon the re-equipping of the R.A.A.F. although a mission has been abroad 18 months ago to examine new types of aircraft.

speech.para: I say, with great respect, that if any person is in a position to speak about the state of our defence services, it is surely Sir Frederick Shedden.

talk.start.para: - If anything is amiss with our defence services he is the man to blame.

- Is that so? Surely if any persons are to be blamed, they are the persons who, as the responsible Ministers, are answerable to the Senate, and to the people. Certainly, there are quite enough of them administering the defence services. Sir Eric Harrison and Sir Philip McBride each have a finger in the defence pie, and then there are the Minister for the Army (Mr. Cramer), the Minister for the Navy (Senator O'sullivan) and the Minister for Air (Mr. Townley). In view of the fact that there are five Ministers administering the defence departments, and that an immense amount of money has been expended on defence since the present Government assumed office, there should not have been any opportunity for the ex-secretary of the Defence Department to utter the words that 1 have mentioned.

speech.para: The Attorney - General (Senator O'sullivan), in answer to the address of the Leader of the Opposition (Senator McKenna), said that the Labour party believes that a system of prices control will, solve all our problems. The Labour party has never said that. We have said that with a system of controls such as would be found in a planned economy we should never have been in the inflationary position that we are in at the present time. Irrespective of how the Government and its spokesmen have decried controls, it is rather interesting to find in this present year of grace that the Government is agreeing to impose what it considers to be selective controls. The Government apparently knows what selective controls are, and no doubt will explain them in due course. Labour has always known where it stands on these matters, and a remark such as that to which I have referred ill becomes the Attorney-General who also holds the position of Leader of the Government in the Senate. The Attorney-General also said that in the past some honorable senators of the Labour party have stated that we should not go short of money, and have advocated that we should go to the printing presses and turn out currency, and also issue bank credit. I want to know where a speech made by any honorable senators on this side of the chamber in which such views are stated are to be found. It ill becomes the Leader of the Government in the Senate to answer the constructive arguments of the Opposition - which have been put forward for years and which were summed up in Senator McKenna's speech - in the way in which he did answer them. One is led to the opinion that the Attorney-General has been using the old political dodge of putting up aunt sallys and then knocking them down.
