Senator Wright seemed to stress his membership of the Liberal party rather than of the Liberal party-Country party coalition, so let us consider some of the statements that he made. He was much concerned with the volume of taxes that will be collected by this Government during the present financial year. He was at variance with Government policy, and suggested that capital works should be financed out of revenue in these times of inflation. He was not concerned with the fact that all such finance has to be raised by taxation, simply because the Government which he supports is not able to obtain the loan money necessary to meet maturing loan commitments and to finance State works. He also complained about death duties which he considered so harsh, and advocated the abolition of the gift duty which he also considered onerous. Of course he believed that by the abolition of death duty and gift duty we should get out of our economic troubles.

I agree with him on one point, and that is the tariff protection given to Australian industries. I believe that we have been prone to hand out tariff protection without being certain in our own minds that the industry warranted such help. I cannot place my finger on any particular example, but I have known cases where tariffs were not used for the purpose for which they were granted.

Senator Wright condemned the recent legislation to revise the measures relating to industrial arbitration. Although he. condemned the Conciliation and Arbitration Act 1956, he suggested that the Arbitration Court should deal with the periodical reviews of wages and conditions. Those reviews, in his opinion, should replace the normal cost of living adjustments that the workers have been accustomed to have for many years. Senator Wright also condemned the transport policy of the Government, and no doubt he had in mind the amendments to the legislation on stevedoring. Senator Wright should be the last person to say anything about the transport policy of this Government or any other government if his remarks are connected with the Stevedoring Industry Act 1956, because I have never seen another man with a sense of responsibility do what Senator Wright did when that measure was before the Senate. When a man declares that he is prepared to follow his words with his vote, one expects him to do so. I wonder whether we can place too much credence in Senator Wright in future if he states that action will follow his words.

He referred last night to the decline in the income of primary producers in recent years. His figures were correct, and I asked him to state the reason for the decline. The first reason was the fall in wool prices. I am pleased to note that there has been a slight recovery, but there were other factors in the decline of farm incomes by £105,000,000 in recent years. The fact is that costs have got out of hand. The Australian Labour party has been saying that for years. We did not want controls. When land prices were pegged, supporters of this Government and its counterparts in the States were urging the abolition of controls.

Is it any wonder that, even at this late hour, the Minister for Immigration (Mr. Harold Holt) and the Acting Prime Minister (Sir Arthur Fadden) told the State Premiers at a conference held in Canberra recently that we were pricing ourselves out of world markets? Every one knew that prices would rise when controls were lifted. I will not say that every one knew that they would go as high as they have gone, but a rise was inevitable. The responsibility lies with Senator Wright and other supporters of this Government because it removed the pegs that held prices. Is it not a fact that, in 1949, when the economy was handed over to this Government-

talk.start.para: - It was never worse.
- I did not believe that any responsible member of a political party would say that. Senator Mattner knows it is not true.
- It is true.

- Senator Mattner knows that the economy of Australia at that time was second to only one in the British Commonwealth of Nations, and that was in the sister dominion of Canada. From 1941 to 1949, the Labour government proved its efficiency in administration, including the conduct of a war. History and the statisticians have recorded that.
- The majority of the people did not think so.

- The majority of the people did not believe in the proposal of the Labour government to nationalize banking. They had a perfect right to record their votes. They knew that it was a drastic step to take, but the fact is that the Labour government was not defeated on the score that it had left the national economy in a bad state.
- Why was it defeated, then?

- The people did not believe in the Labour government's policy of. bank nationalization. Let me return to Senator Wright. I recall that famous night when he made his valiant speech. I remember that he said what he would do, and how he stopped outside when the vote was taken. It was not even a retreat because he did not come into the chamber to retreat. He has complained that the interest bill of the farming community has risen by £12,000,000 in the last four years. I agree, but does not Senator Wright believe that the Administration has something to answer for in that connexion? It has had power over interest rates. Between 1941 and 1949, the Labour government could get loans over-subscribed at interest rates of 3i per cent, and 3i per cent. Interest rates are rising, and the burden is falling on the backs of the primary producers. Senator Wright must bear his responsibility for some portion of it. By supporting the Government, he and others are responsible. May I finish with Senator Wright by saying that it seems to me he is willing to wound but he will not strike. I thought I had some responsibility at least to answer Senator Wright. I do not think people should come into this chamber and attempt- to make heroes of themselves by criticizing, and then, when the acid is turned on them to support their criticisms by their vote, absent themselves from the division.

speech.para: Dealing with the question before us, I have yet to read a budget speech which, to my mind, is colder or more callous. The Government is only reaping the whirlwind. It said, " Put us into office and you need have no fears ".

talk.start.para: - No wonder the words of Jeremiah were quoted to-night.

- What I say is true, and honorable senators opposite cannot get away from it. At least, they ought to be big enough to admit their mistake. I am no Jeremiah at all; I am concerned in the main about people on the lower incomes. It has been said, in effect, by the Government that the present economic position is due chiefly to two causes, namely, that we are expanding too rapidly and that with such an expansion we are achieving too high a consumption of goods.
- That is just about right.

- The honorable -senator admits that that is just about right. Let us have a look at the first cause. Taking the Government's own figures from the budget speech, the national income has risen by £265,000,000 or 6.5 per cent. If one reads the Treasury's information bulletin for July one finds that the overall rise in prices over the same period - since the last budget until to-day - has been 6.5 per cent. As far as money values are concerned, one wants to know whence the huge increase has come. The increase of 6.5 per cent, in national income, I say, and I defy contradiction, - should automatically cancel out when prices rise by 6.5 per cent. When one reads : further from the information that is so readily at one's hand, one finds that in countries like "Argentina, Austria, Finland, France, West Germany, Italy and Norway there has been an increase of income in real terms.

speech.para: I turn to the second cause of our difficult economic position, namely, that we desire a much too high standard of living. I ask honorable senators: Have the workers under federal awards, which have been stationary since 1953, caused this rise in living standards? They have had no cost of living increases. On the figures available they constitute about half of the working population of this country. Have they enjoyed too high a standard of living? Have the people on fixed incomes, let alone the pensioners, enjoyed too high a standard of living during the last year?

talk.start.para: - Who have?

- I ask the honorable senator. The only people who seem to have enjoyed a high standard of living, if my memory serves me correctly, are the 22 per cent, of the people who enjoy 40 per cent, of the national income of this country. The figures I have quoted are taken in the main from the United Nations publication dated May, 1956, giving statistics of national income and expenditure.

speech.para: I should have liked to have spent some time considering the subject of the balance of payments. It is true that owing to our cost structure we. are finding it rather embarrassing to sell some of our primary products overseas. Unless we can export more goods, this crazy system of " on and off " import restrictions seemingly will have to go on for quite a long time. If import restrictions were technically applied, one could not find much objection to them; but the Government imposes restrictions, rights the position, and then takes some of the restrictions off, or at least takes some of the favoured imports out of the ordinary category, as it did in the case of newsprint. That is done in order to help the bosses of the men upstairs because it is they who keep the Government in office. The importation of newsprint was taken out of the normal processes and put under the control of the Minister. I ask honorable senators: Is that done in order to make certain that newsprint imports will be cut as are other articles in the same category? If it is, why single newsprint out in that way?

Is it done in order that newsprint may get favoured treatment? That vis all I ask. Why the need for this? If the officers who handle import restrictions are regarded by the Minister as fit to deal with the vast majority of other items coming within that category, what is wrong with letting them deal with newsprint? Why put it under the administration of the Minister? If it is not to get favoured treatment, it seems to me that there is no trust in the officers.

talk.start.para: - The honorable senator has a suspicious mind.
- I have not a suspicious mind at all.
- Many other items are administered by the Minister also.

- No doubt the honorable senator has means of obtaining information which is not available to honorable senators on this side, and before he makes his speech I ask him to find what is the number of articles that come. within the import restriction range, also the number that are dealt with in the normal way and the number that receive special treatment. I will not call the honorable senator suspicious, and if he can prove to me that my contention is wrong, I will be the first to admit it. But I do not think that he will be able to produce either the numbers or the lists for which I have asked, because they will not weigh in his favour.

speech.para: Other items will be discussed when the Estimates are dealt with, and at this stage I only wish to add that I am inclined to believe that the time will come when pensions will have to be dealt with in another sphere. It is fantastic that if it cost £4 a week to keep one pensioner last year, he should be expected to live on the same amount now that prices have risen by at least 6.5 per cent, ls he to eat less because prices have risen? I agree with the honorable senator who said that the position of a single pensioner is perhaps harder than that of a married pensioner couple - however hard that may be. But surely we arc humane enough to say that the pensioners deserve financial assistance so that they may have the same quantity to eat, the same amount of clothes to wear and be able to live a normal life as they did last year, and it is up to this Government to provide the means for them to do it.

In a budget involving' £1,200,000,000, the allocation of £10,500,000 or £11,000,000 would have given an increase of 7s. 6d. a week to every pensioner. In asking for that, surely one is not asking much. This Government has largely failed by not providing for those who are in greatest need of help. But if it is courageous enough, even after this budget is passed, to bring down a bill to lighten the burden of the pensioners, it will have the approbation of all sections of the people.

talk.start.para: . - First of all, I wish to congratulate the three new senators who spoke to-night. The Senate is fortunate in having three men who will so greatly add to its debating strength, and to the wit and humour without which the debate becomes dogmatic, polemic and partisan. I wish, also, to congratulate the Treasurer on having brought down his ninth budget.

speech.para: I propose to trace the development that has taken place under this Government, lt is true that the budget is largely concerned with the stresses and strains in the economy, and with efforts that are necessary to meet them. That is inevitable, and it has happened with every budget. But behind the story of this budget is the story of a nation that has progressed marvellously within the last six years. In 1941, 1 doubt whether any of us believed that Australia would have achieved such rapid development as is apparent to-day. There is one chapter, however, which is not as satisfactory as it should be, and that is the falling-off in farm income. This subject was ably dealt with last night by Senator Wright, and 1 merely add that it is not sufficient to develop our secondary industries, a larger population and greater national income if primary production, which is the basis of all our prosperity, is falling off.

The most promising feature which 1 saw in my travels through the Commonwealth during the last recess is the great prospect for the mining industry. Mining is one of our great primary industries, and I am happy to feel that the future for it is brighter than it has ever been. We are in the dawn of a very great era, and I put my hope for the building up of our export income largely in the extractive industries.

The budget sets forth the ways and means by which the Government proposes to relieve the stresses and strains in our economy. Inflation is the effect of so many causes that it would be impossible in one speech to sort them out- and deal with them effectively. Consequently, I can select only one or two matters, haphazardly. One is the irresponsible attitude of the States since uniform taxation was introduced. This is a well-worn theme, and I know that people outside Parliament, as well as honorable senators in this chamber, will say that it is not much good talking about it. The question is, when is something going to be done? I emphasize the point, however, that it is not fair to throw the whole responsibility on the present Government. The Commonwealth Government has expressed its willingness to hand taxing powers back to the States, and it is the unwillingness of some of the States and the half-hearted negative attitude of others that has caused the position to remain at a standstill. It is my emphatic opinion that the State governments will never develop a feeling of responsibility until they are compelled to raise the greater part of their revenue for themselves and until they are forced to accept the responsibility for the expenditure they inflict upon the community. In my view, one of the major causes of inflation is the fact that we are compelled, because of the state of the loan market, to finance the greater part of State works out of revenue while having no say in just what work should be proceeded with first.

I think the most important thing that has assisted inflation has been our immigration policy. I know that in the long run it will have a deflationary effect, and I know that immigration is necessary if we are to build up a proper economy. I also know that the whole matter has not been sorted out properly yet and, therefore, people may throw figures at me to prove, in a debating sense, that what I am saying is wrong. But if we look at what our immigrants are costing in the way of schools, housing and other amenities until they become producers, I think it will be agreed that immigration has a great inflationary force. I realize that to some extent that is cancelled by the contribution the immigrants make, but I do not know the extent to which it is offset by those circumstances. Some of our industries, our building industry in particular, depend largely on the efforts of our immigrants, but nobody has been able to cast up the accounts and show how far immigration has been either inflationary or deflationary in its effect. The fact is that it entails enormous expenditure; and we have to pay some attention to the number of immigrants we can absorb. I am fully in favour of our admitting the greatest number that can be absorbed in the economy, but I feel that we are looking at it in the wrong way if we look upon our immigration policy as being merely one of putting up money solely to attract immigrants by advertising for them, by having officers overseas to encourage them, and so on. In my view, the most important part of our immigration policy should be the building up of those parts of the economy which are necessary for the proper functioning of all the activities of the community. I shall deal with that aspect in more detail when 1 am discussing the question of transport later.

In reply to Senator McManus, I should say that the reduction in the number of immigrants from southern Europe was not made because the Government, or anybody else, looked upon those people as inferior migrants. The plain fact is that it is easier at present to get immigrants from certain southern European countries than it is to get them from other places. I know that there is a long waiting list, because 1 have been trying for four years to get permission for an immigrant to enter Australia from a southern European country, purely on compassionate grounds. The other members of his family have come out here and are good citizens. He does not happen to have the physical standard we require, but 1 have at last obtained from the immigration authorities permission for this man to enter. If immigrants prove to be good citizens, I do not think we should deny them the right to bring out another member of the family, particularly when they are ready to guarantee that this" other member of the family will not be a charge upon the community. All that the Immigration Department has done up to the present has been to attempt to secure a proper balance. It is unfortunate that the number of British immigrants has been reduced because of the lack of shipping resulting from the Suez crisis and from other causes. While we welcome immigrants from the whole of western Europe, as well as from southern Europe, we do not wish any particular nationality to predominate, but we certainly wish to preserve a balance in favour of the inhabitants of the British Isles.

If we are to maintain our immigration stream at the present level, or at any high level, it is essential that we import capital. It is impossible to finance our immigration programme solely out of our own savings. We are hard put to it to finance the ordinary development of the country, and even if our population were increasing only at the slow rate that it was in the 1930's, we should still find ' it hard to finance the increase out of our own savings. If we are to add to our population a stream of hundreds of thousands of immigrants a year we must get capital from overseas.' That capital can be obtained only by borrowing, and the borrowing should be both public and private. I know that there is a false idea abroad about borrowing. People look upon it as putting ourselves in pawn, as giving somebody overseas the right to draw on us in the future. It is quite true that we do that, but it is necessary to do so because there is no other way of securing capital goods. The important thing to remember is that when we get a loan abroad, whether it is made to the Government or through company investment, it means bringing capital goods such as plant, machinery and so on into the country. No country has developed without the importation of capital in great measure. In a society such as the one in which we live, it is necessary to be, a debtor country during the period of development. The standard of living of a debtor country can be very high, and the people of a debtor country can be very happy. During the whole of the nineteenth century, and indeed, right up to the end of World War I., the United States of America was a debtor country. The greater part of the capital goods in the country had come from overseas. Millions of pounds poured in to the United States, and America's development enriched people in Great Britain, France and other European countries. We must follow along those lines.

The only other way of colonising a new country of which I am aware is the way in which Russia has colonised and is colonising Siberia. Some people may prefer that way, but 1 am sure the Australian people as a whole do not. That being so, it iswrong that every time a loan is raised we should have the sneer that we are putting, the country in pawn. What we are actually doing is bringing capital goods to the country. One of my most interesting, experiences was to visit Leigh Creek and see there the enormous amount of machinery that had been imported from overseas on. borrowed money. That machinery was. being used to lift coal, and I had never seen anything like it before. We have only totravel through the country and see the modern earth-moving machinery and new methods of extraction being put into operation in mines to appreciate what capital can do. The Snowy Mountains hydroelectric scheme is an excellent example of what capital can do. It has shown that it is good to have private capital brought in by overseas companies which bring in not only their money but also their equipment and skilled technicians. As the great Snowy Mountains hydro-electric scheme goes forward to fruition we see the benefit of having American, Swedish, French, British and other capital here.

Sir Earle Page, in a very interesting speech delivered in another place, propounded a, scheme which I think would be well worth while our examining. It was a scheme calculated to persuade companies to come here with capital and equipment. He proposed giving such companies what he called a self-liquidating franchise to do certain things. The system has been adopted in European and other countries. Companies, were given land cheaply, and allowed various other concessions to build railways, or embark upon other undertakings on the condition that at the end of a certain period the whole capital enterprise would revert to the nation concerned. The nation could then operate the system or, if it liked, sell; it. That would not put the country in pawn* and, in the long run, the scheme would bearconsiderable fruit.

I should like to emphasize that J. believe-' in the maintenance of a steady stream of immigrants to this country. I should likethe intake to be as high as possible, but I do not think that it is right for peopleto pluck a figure out of the air, or for an' intake figure to be determined arbitrarily, as we did for one or two years. Because- of the. great strains that immigration imposes on the economy,, the intake should be a matter for careful consideration, lest the cost involved ruin the entire scheme. Perhaps the worst enemies of our immigration policy are those uncritical admirers who regard as unpatriotic any person who attempts to introduce a rational element into it.

We have heard a great deal to-night about the burden of the budget falling on those least able to bear it. Who are they? They are the people with fixed incomes, the business people who can only sell in a completely competitive market, and those whom we regard as a separate class, the exporters, whose prices are fixed overseas. As far as the people on fixed incomes are concerned, one class - the pensioners - is directly affected. I think that there should be a good deal of re-thinking about Government policy in this connexion.

As honorable senators, know, when age pensions were first introduced;, they were intended to relieve the indigent. They were :not intended to be a form of superannuation for the great bulk of the population, but, as a result of a steadily developing process, that has come about, and I think most of us accept it. However, that was never intended, and' we cannot hope to provide for everybody in this country who attains a certain age because, if we select a relatively low age - as we do now - an undue burden is placed, not on the rich, whether idle or active, but on the working members of the community.

Since the system of age pensions was inaugurated, the average duration of life has extended enormously. I believe that - I am quoting from far back reading and not from any immediate figures - the average duration of life has increased by at least fifteen years within the last 50 years. It is no longer right to regard three score and ten years as the span of the normal life. A person of strong constitution, who has led a reasonable life, has a very good prospect of living at least ten years, or fifteen years longer than the psalmists who lived 2,000 or 3,000 years ago regarded as the normal span. I regard it as completely wrong for any man in normal health to have to cease work on attaining 65 years of age.

It may be necessary to prescribe retiring ages for certain sections of the community, such as the Public Service, but that does not necessarily mean that a person who retires, at the prescribed age must cease to lead an active life. For myself, I should regard the rest of my life as an earthly purgatory if I were condemned to idleness in a few years' time. I certainly believe in the philosophy of the man Kipling mentions who, at a great congress, said to Kaiser Wilhelm II., " I guess I shall work until I drop ". I think that that is a sounder philosophy than the belief that a person should cease all activity in the community when he reaches the age of 65 years.

But there is a real problem involved. It is the problem of the indigent - the people who are really in need. I do not know exactly how we can single them out, but 1 am convinced that they are much fewer in number than the people who are at present entitled to draw the age pension. I know perfectly well that many people who are drawing age pensions are quite well to do. They are people who have worked, and are working. Under our generous social service laws, they may have a house and certain sources of income.

talk.start.para: - Not too generous!

- As Senator Critchley does not like the term " generous ", I shall say that, under our just laws, those people are entitled to draw a certain amount of money from the public revenue. But they are not indigent if they own a house, and have other sources of income and may, in addition, earn money. The real problem is not one that can be solved by shedding crocodile tears, and saying things merely because they are popular and will gain votes. The real problem is to identify those who are indigent and in need of monetary assistance. We must find some way of doing that. One step that this Government has taken has been to subsidize the provision of homes for indigent people. I regard that as a major contribution to social welfare.

speech.para: I shall now deal briefly with the subject of taxation, to which reference has been -made by honorable senators on both sides. I agree with those who see in various forms of indirect taxation a great deal that is undesirable. There was a time when I was completely opposed to sales tax. I am reconciled now to certain aspects of sales tax because, due to the strains on our economy, it is necessary to dampen down expenditure in various directions. However, I think that we should scrutinize carefully every year the lists of articles subject u> sales tax, and we should suggest to the Treasurer items that ought to be freed from sales tax.

There is one tax that I, myself, regard as completely wrong and iniquitous. I refer to the pay-roll tax. I can find nothing to justify it except that it is easy to collect and brings in revenue of about £45,000,000 a year. For that reason, it might be difficult for the Treasury to abandon it.

talk.start.para: - It was imposed to enable the payment of child endowment.

- That is so, but nevertheless I believe that it is inflationary in its effect. It is a hindrance to business, and I think that it should be abolished. The leeway in revenue could be made up by the adjustment of other forms of taxation. I believe that there is justification for certain forms of indirect taxation, particularly excise and customs duty, because it is necessary to leave to the people, whether their income be large or small, sufficient money to encourage them to save, and thus relieve the country of a burden in their old age. I could have dealt with a number of other matters, but this is a subject to which I have given a great deal of thought. I hope that my remarks have not been without value. Despite its few defects, I regard the budget as a sound one and reasonably suited to our times.
- I rise with great diffidence at this hour to address the Senate and the few people who may be listening over the radio.
- There are thousands of them.

- I hope that the honorable senator is right, because it is somewhat distressing to speak to so few honorable senators in this chamber. One is met with circumstances which give a feeling of frustration. Sometimes I wonder whether it is worth while speaking at all and whether the most excellent speeches made in this chamber have any real effect. To-night we have heard some excellent speeches from new senators, and I take this opportunity to compliment them on their utterances. At the same time, I inform them, after having been in this Senate for 25 years, that their remarks will not go very far; they will have practically no effect on the Treasurer (Sir Arthur Fadden) and his colleagues, and will not alter in the slightest degree the policy which the Government has laid down and to which it is committed. Many other honorable senators believe, as I do, that the Parliament has lost its power over the Executive, which consists of a few members of the Ministry who decide what shall be done; and the Senate and the House of Representatives are left without control. However, I have been asked to speak, and I must do my job, which means that I must do my best to interest honorable senators and myself. I believe that in the multitude of counsellors there is wisdom, and certainly I am convinced that much wisdom resides in the Senate. There is also a lot of mental obfuscation.
- There are some Jeremiahs, too.

- Like Senator Hannan, I could quote from the Bible, but I shall not do so to-night. I was somewhat amazed at the honorable senator's quotation from the Book of Jeremiah, but I remember that honorable senators opposite have the habit of digging into ancient records and using the remarks of people of past ages in support of some argument applying to modern times. The present Government is moribund and unable to cope with the situation confronting this country in the way that it should and would act if it were fully aware of modern ' trends and developments. Unfortunately, members of the Government are static in their approach to problems, and for that reason they are unable to overcome them. The trouble is that the Government has been in office too long. It has been in charge of the country for seven years, and now it is sitting back in the breeching. Some one has said that, like Micawber, the Government is waiting for something to turn up. The Treasurer has been the recipient of much criticism and advice, much of which has come from members of the Government parties. He has, of course, been eulogized by some, but, at the same time, members of the tory parties have criticized him a good deal during recent weeks.

speech.para: During this debate speeches delivered in this chamber have covered a wide range of subjects, including the extension of the powers of the Snowy Mountains Hydroelectric Authority. I commend Senator Buttfield for her interesting contribution to the debate. As one who sat for eight years in the presidential chair, I can appreciate the position when an honorable senator rises and deals with a subject as objectively and capably as Senator Buttfield did last night. I commend her not only for the manner in which she spoke, but also for the matter contained in her speech. Senator Maher, that genial senator from Queensland, would solve the problem of inflation by getting boys and girls to make compulsory savings. His suggestion sounds all right, but it reminds me of King Canute trying to keep back the incoming tide. Another honorable senator suggested that the main burden of taxes should be transferred from married taxpayers to single taxpayers, and I suppose he meant well.

One of the proposals most popular with supporters of the Government is that the economy of Australia could be saved, and inflation arrested, by decreasing wages. They claim that in that way the ship of state could be put on an even keel. It is the policy of the Government to ask members of the working class in the community to tighten their belts, eat less porridge and fewer potatoes and half starve their wives and children. They claim that by lowering wages Australia could compete in the world markets with England and the United States of America, and that all would be well.

talk.start.para: - Senator Buttfield advocated that we should eat more rice.

- The honorable senator told us that the Chinese people averaged 600 lb. of rice a year according to the statistician's figures. I am reminded that the late Joseph Silver Collings, who was at one time a member of the Senate, said that there are three kinds of liars - liars, damned liars, and statisticians. According to statistics, there are between 600,000,000 and 1,000,000,000 Chinese in the world. If each of them eats 600 lb. of rice a year, they would consume more rice than the world produces. I leave it at that.
- The honorable senator should know that 600 lb. of rice a year is less than 2 lb. a day.
- I like rice, but I should not like to eat 2 lb. of it a day.
- My figures were right.
- Of course. However, I was somewhat amused by the honorable senator's remarks, and I suppose I have a right to be amused.

speech.para: Another suggestion to meet the situation was made by Sir Earle Christmas Grafton Page, who made the astounding proposal that some of our public utilities should be handed over to private enterprise. I have no doubt that that suggestion found favour with our good friend the Minister for National Development (Senator Spooner), who, when he passes to the happy hunting ground, will have engraved on his heart the words " private enterprise ". Apparently, Sir Earle Page would pass over to private enterprise the Post Office and our railways. I say now that the Labour party is strongly opposed to anything of that kind being done, because we believe that if we are to solve our problems and avoid fluctuations in our economic processes, we must draw as much as possible from private capitalism and place it where it will be controlled by the people, through the government acting on their behalf.

We do not say, with the Communists, that we shall take full and complete control of all industry, and of every little shop and paddock in the country. The Labour party is a party of realists, and we say to the people that if we are to avoid the ups and downs, fluctuations, unemployment and misery that occur as the result of private enterprise controlling the economy of the country, we must follow the line of control of industry by the people, and take control away from the gamblers of the stock exchange and from the exponents of private enterprise who would sacrifice the country in order to gain a little gold, lt is one of the fundamental principles of the Labour party that vital industries, when they are not being run properly by private enterprise, should be taken over by the State, and runin the interests of the community.

I listened with great surprise and deep interest to our good friend Senator Henty who went to see Chiang Kai-Shek in Formosa, where there are no flies. In fact, Senator Henty gave what might be considered to be a Communist speech when he told us what is being done in Formosa, where they have actually liquidated the landlords. We do not advise the liquidation of landlords, but we do say that we should use the land of our country, not for the purpose of exploitation, but to feed the people.

Senator Maher had a solution for our problems. I always enjoy listening to Senator Maher because he is such an old tory troglodyte - although I do not say that in an offensive manner. About 25 years ago in this chamber I called Senator Payne, from Tasmania, an old troglodyte. He was very upset about it, and rose with tears in his eyes and anger in his face and appealed to the then President of the Senate, colourful old Paddy Lynch. A week before, Paddy had beaten Senator Payne in the contest for the job of President, and was not too kindly disposed to the old troglodyte from Tasmania. Senator Payne asked for a withdrawal of the word " troglodyte ", which I had applied to him. Paddy looked up at me and I could see a glint in his eye. He said, " Possibly the honorable senator has a dictionary meaning for the term troglodyte ". I said, " Yes, during the course of my long historical reading I discovered that thousands of years ago men and women lived in caves. They were known as troglodytes. Senator Payne is not a cave-dweller, but mentally he is on the same level ". When I listen to some of the honorable senators on the Government side I must say - without being offensive because I have no anger or bitterness in my heart - and I think when they are discussing economics and international relationships their minds go back to the primaeval slime and they have not progressed at all.

Senator Maher suggested that prices, wages and other charges should be reduced by 20 per cent. Some one interjected and said, " What about mortgages ", but Senator Maher jibbed at mortgages. Many, years ago, an old relative of mine told me that he could run the country, and one of the ways in which he would improve things would be to reduce all costs by 50 per cent.

I asked him why they should not be cut out altogether, so that we could all. be happy. I will not say what he replied to that because I am on the air, but ideas similar to Senator Maher's have been put forward by different people for a long time. Such persons have no conception of the economic position in which this country now finds itself, nor of the world position as a whole. They think that they can counter inflation by some petty little method that has been evolved in a troglodytic mind.

Inflationary problems such as we have are just as acute in England. They are the problems of modern financial monopoly capitalism, but I ask honorable senators not to think that I am a Communist because I have mentioned capitalism. We are still living in a capitalist era, and the sameproblems as we have arise also in other capitalist countries. I have before me a report in the " Christian Science Monitor '\ which is a very good American newspaper. The newspaper was provided free to me through the generosity of the management of the Hotel Kurrajong. Apparently, those papers are sent to the hotel for distribution among benighted and ignorant senators and other politicians. Being benighted andsomewhat ignorant, I accepted one. According to the article in this newspaper Sir Anthony Eden recently delivered a speech in an attempt to rouse the British workmen from their lethargy. In that speech he used arguments similar to the arguments that the Government uses when it is trying to explain how we should solve our problems.

Sir Anthony said that the struggle against inflation was the battle which the few - referring to the few who won the Battle of Britain - could not win to-day, as they did against Hitler. He said that Britain was in mortal peril, not of immediate unemployment, but of dire poverty by stages. He also said that Britain must halt rising prices, produce more of better quality and sell it at competitive prices. I can almost hear Senator Spooner, brother Sir Arthur Fadden and comrade Bob Menzies saying the same thing-

talk.start.para: - Order! The honorable senator must not refer to members in another place in that way. He must refer to them in the correct manner.

- I have heard the Prime Minister, Mr. Robert Menzies, Sir Arthur Fadden and other members of another place speak in a way similar to that of Sir Anthony Eden. Sir Anthony went further, and said that the English people must take steps to build up their gold and dollar reserves. I point out that this Government is saying the same sort of thing about our reserves in England. Sir Anthony also said that imports and home consumption in England were too high, and that England was importing too much and consuming too much. That has also been said about this great land of plenty. So that we will not get into a bog of economic disaster, the Liberal Government is refusing to give justice to age and invalid pensioners. It believes that, to keep the country on an even keel, we must not be fair and just and Christian in our actions towards them. Instead of giving them an extra £1 a week, we are refusing them anything.

speech.para: We are being told to work harder and longer, but the Government has not said a word about the usurers. I cannot find words to describe the persons who will use their power over finance to drag from people who want money 10 per cent., 15 per cent, and 20 per cent, by way of interest. How low they are, and yet they call themselves good Australians. The Government is not doing anything to stop this usury. Shylock was a Christian beside them. Has there been any increase in the labour time that is needed to produce goods? Why should commodity goods be dearer? I should like to refer to one item - refrigerators. Recently, in. a spirit of prodigality, I said to my wife, " My dear wife, we will buy a new refrigerator ". I went to inquire about the price of various refrigerators, and had a long conversation with the manager of one establishment We discussed hire purchase, and he said that if I wanted to buy a refrigerator on the hire-purchase system, they would have to charge me interest. I asked him what rate of interest. He said, " I suppose it will run out at about 12 per cent, at a flat rate, but if you go down the road you will find that, by the time you have paid for your refrigerator, you will have been charged 17± per cent." Those are the Christian gentlemen who are exploiting the workers.

One refrigerator was priced at £225. There was another for £189. I began to make inquiries, and found that the labour costs to build the refrigerator I have in my home totalled £25. It is a cheap refrigerator that was in the house when I bought it. The price on the market was £130. The difference between £25 and £130 is swallowed up by usury, commission and advertising, because there is a cartel to keepprices up.

One day my refrigerator broke down,, and I called in a man to mend it. He charged me a high price. He told me that he was doing refrigeration work for business people, and the companies added 50* per cent, on to his charges. When they discovered that he was doing the work at a. good profit at his own price, the companies got busy and he could get no more steel for his refrigeration business.

talk.start.para: - This is. prosperity!

- Yes, and those are the rotten tactics of those who have a monopoly, even in the refrigerator business. There are monopolies everywhere, yet some pinheaded, mental featherweights say that they will burst the monopolies. The monopolies will burst them before they succumb.

speech.para: I wish to refer briefly to a matter that I spoke about in this chamber recently. I am afraid that I used words that I should not have used in relation to exploitation of persons who had suffered some disability, were rehabilitated and then were sacked from their jobs. I have had the best of help from the Deputy-Director of Social! Services in Brisbane. The men who have been in charge there have been most sympathetic, and will stretch the law, if possible, to do service to some poor person to whom nature has not been kind.

A man I have in mind was crippled fifteen years ago with poliomyelitis. It is pitiful to see him getting about his house on his rear because he has no power in his legs. He was rehabilitated and obtained a job. He was in it for nine months before be was sacked. He speaks very highly of the firm, but there was a shortage of work. He was able to get _ the pension again, and then the firm sent for him. After two months, he was sacked again, and this time he could' not get the pension. He was given about half the pension by way of unemployment benefit. He was totally and permanently incapacitated, and he saved the nation hundreds of pounds by being rehabilitated! so that he could work. He could not find another job, and the Department of Social Services, working under the law, had to reduce him to half pay. I have referred this matter to the Minister for Social Services (Mr. Roberton) but have not had a reply. I hope that something will be done for the totally and permanently incapacitated cripples when they lose their jobs. They should be given a pension. I ask for leave to continue my remarks.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.
